conversation:
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down. This Sharran exposed a traitor in your midst.
Isobel: Fair. I admit, Marcus waltzing around the place undetected bodes rather ill for our defences, doesn't it? Then again, the best defence is a good offence. Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle. But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I'm glad you've remembered who needs whose help here.
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: Nod. Better to humour her than make an enemy of all in this place. Lady Shar will understand.
Isobel: Refreshingly pragmatic of you. I sense Shar has offered some amount of protection to you already, but... well, no harm in extra precaution - even from a Sel√ªnite.
Player: Try to understand what's happening.
Narrator: *Is Lady Shar punishing you? Or perhaps testing you? Is it the tadpole, or a curse? You cannot say.*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance. This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is. Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: The Dark Lady's works aren't for me to question.
Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we? I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I've already been to Moonrise, but I have more work to do indeed.
Isobel: I imagine so, if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing off into the night.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Isobel: Hold - who are you, and what are you doing here?
Narrator: *Your body yearns to kill this cleric, more than anything else. You know it, deep down, in your writhing intestines.*
Player: My blood... it's telling me to kill you.
Isobel: And yet you hesitate.
Narrator: *She doesn't believe you will do it. You can see, she wants to believe there is mercy in all, even in the worst.*
Isobel: You aren't the first to threaten me. But I know the eyes of a killer when I see them. You mean me no harm. Do you? An experienced cleric can tell such things.
Narrator: *The Urge within does not want to talk. The restless Urge starts to scream.*
Player: Chase away your putrid desires.
Narrator: *As suddenly as it started, you have tamed the Urge. It slumbers again.*
Isobel: There we are. The real you. Your - affliction, is it? - doesn't rule you, does it.
Player: I'm cursed with spells of madness, forgive me what I said.
Isobel: Why don't we try again, then? Who are you? Hold - who are you, and what are you doing here?
Narrator: *Your body yearns to kill this cleric, more than anything else. You know it, deep down, in your writhing intestines.*
Player: My blood... it's telling me to kill you.
Isobel: And yet you hesitate.
Narrator: *She doesn't believe you will do it. You can see, she wants to believe there is mercy in all, even in the worst.*
Isobel: You aren't the first to threaten me. But I know the eyes of a killer when I see them. You mean me no harm. Do you? An experienced cleric can tell such things.
Narrator: *The Urge within does not want to talk. The restless Urge starts to scream.*
Player: Chase away your putrid desires.
Narrator: *As suddenly as it started, you have tamed the Urge. It slumbers again.*
Isobel: There we are. The real you. Your - affliction, is it? - doesn't rule you, does it.
Player: I'm cursed with spells of madness, forgive me what I said.
Isobel: Why don't we try again, then? Who are you? Hold - who are you, and what are you doing here?

Player: Chase away your putrid desires.
Narrator: *As suddenly as it started, you have tamed the Urge. It slumbers again.*

Player: I'm cursed with spells of madness, forgive me what I said.
Isobel: Why don't we try again, then? Who are you? Hold - who are you, and what are you doing here?
Narrator: *Your body yearns to kill this cleric, more than anything else. You know it, deep down, in your writhing intestines.*
Player: I'm [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53]. I mean you no harm.
Isobel: You'd be a bit late to the party if you did. Ketheric Thorm done for. Or didn't you see that angel carving a path straight toward Moonrise Towers?
Player: Attack her. The Urge aches for it.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale holds out his arm. Above the palm of his hand is conjured in gold-coloured magic the image of a woman, the goddess Mystra. He's looking at the figure intensely.
Player: Pretty.
Gale: Oh! My, you startled me. I... I was miles away.
NodeContext: Gale is looking at a miniature magical projection of Mystra he's created in his hand in his hand. Startled, he dispells it.
Player: Is everything all right?
Gale: Of course, of course. I was just... practising an incantation.
Player: If you say so.
Gale: I do - because it's through practice that I seek to perfect. To augment. Magic is... my life. I've been in touch with the Weave for as long as I can remember. There's nothing like it. It's like music, poetry, physical beauty all rolled into one and given expression through the senses. That is why I asked you to seek me out, to offer you a taste of such wonders. Would you like me to show you? Would you like to experience this?
Player: Yes, I would.
Gale: Then follow my lead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale walks around behind the player (as though teaching them to fly a kite) and makes a delicate gesture with both hands.
Gale: Now you.
Player: Imitate the gesture slowly and as precisely as you can.
Narrator: *You feel something strange - like a kind word and a kind touch at the same time. It's warm and comfortable.*
Gale: Excellent. Now repeat after me: Ah-Thran Mystra-Ryl Kantrach-Ao.
Player: Repeat the words, slowly, but carefully. You sense power in these words. Speak them deliberately.
Narrator: *Suddenly: the scent of rosewater and a sense of wellbeing. A sliver of Weave that tastes sweet on the tongue.*
Gale: Very good. Now I want you to picture in your mind the concept of harmony. As true as you can.
Player: Sink deep into your magic. It is who you are. It is home.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The player and Gale are now fully enveloped in a magic glow - a protective field of beautiful magic. Unconsciously player steps back closer to Gale.
Narrator: *You see - or is it sense? - the unmistakable presence of Mystra, the Lady of Mysteries.* *There's something like the anticipation of a kiss, then the pleasure of being cloaked in peace.* *You are safe. You are nestled in the cup of her hand.*
Gale: You did it. You're channelling the Weave. How does it feel?
Player: Incredible. Though of course, I could have managed it by myself...
Gale: You're hard to please, aren't you?
Narrator: *The Weave connects you. The moment feels intimate.*
Player: Hold on to the moment. It's a good night for intimacy.
Narrator: *You realise the Weave is making you one. You have but to imagine your desire, and Gale will know it.*
Player: Picture kicking him in the gut.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale holds out his arm. Above the palm of his hand is conjured in gold-coloured magic the image of a woman, the goddess Mystra. He's looking at the figure intensely.
Player: Pretty.
Gale: Oh! My, you startled me. I... I was miles away.
NodeContext: Gale is looking at a miniature magical projection of Mystra he's created in his hand in his hand. Startled, he dispells it.
Player: Is everything all right?
Gale: Of course, of course. I was just... practising an incantation.
Player: If you say so.
Gale: I do - because it's through practice that I seek to perfect. To augment. Magic is... my life. I've been in touch with the Weave for as long as I can remember. There's nothing like it. It's like music, poetry, physical beauty all rolled into one and given expression through the senses. That is why I asked you to seek me out, to offer you a taste of such wonders. Would you like me to show you? Would you like to experience this?
Player: Yes, I would.
Gale: Then follow my lead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale walks around behind the player (as though teaching them to fly a kite) and makes a delicate gesture with both hands.
Gale: Now you.
Player: Imitate the gesture quickly and decisively.
Narrator: *You feel something strange - like a kind word and a kind touch at the same time. It's warm and comfortable.*
Gale: Excellent. Now repeat after me: Ah-Thran Mystra-Ryl Kantrach-Ao.
Player: Repeat the words, bold and proud. You sense power in these words. Speak them deliberately.
Narrator: *Suddenly: the scent of rosewater and a sense of wellbeing. A sliver of Weave that tastes sweet on the tongue.*
Gale: Very good. Now I want you to picture in your mind the concept of harmony. As true as you can.
Player: Recede into the calm centre of your mind, just like you were taught at the academy.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The player and Gale are now fully enveloped in a magic glow - a protective field of beautiful magic. Unconsciously player steps back closer to Gale.
Narrator: *You see - or is it sense? - the unmistakable presence of Mystra, the Lady of Mysteries.* *There's something like the anticipation of a kiss, then the pleasure of being cloaked in peace.* *You are safe. You are nestled in the cup of her hand.*
Gale: You did it. You're channelling the Weave. How does it feel?
Player: Incredible. Though of course, I could have managed it by myself...
Gale: You're hard to please, aren't you?
Narrator: *The Weave connects you. The moment feels intimate.*
Player: Hold on to the moment. It's a good night for intimacy.
Narrator: *You realise the Weave is making you one. You have but to imagine your desire, and Gale will know it.*
Player: Picture kicking him in the gut.

Nightwarden Minthara: The goblins tell me that you extracted a confession from our prisoner, True Soul. Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood.
Narrator: *Her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
Nightwarden Minthara: You are a True Soul? Little wonder that you serve me so well. It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall. Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: And once I'm inside?
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position. You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike. We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name. And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: Reject these dreams of a bloodbath.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: If I do this, I expect to be rewarded.

Nightwarden Minthara: I do not have time for interruptions, sister.
Narrator: *As she turns to you, her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
NodeContext: unnerved
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player sees a vision of Minthara with Orin, one of the Absolute's chosen.
InternalNodeContext: Cinematic blocked until Orin asset/voice available. Cinematic blocked until Orin asset/voice available.
Nightwarden Minthara: A True Soul? Praise be, sister. Are you here to join my hunt? Her heart is more generous than mine. Join my hunt, faerie. And obey me.
Player: I'm on a hunt of my own. I'm looking for a druid named Halsin.
Nightwarden Minthara: Interesting. What do you know of this druid?
Player: I've heard rumours that he's a very powerful healer.
Nightwarden Minthara: There is no power except for the Absolute. If you are sick, speak to the goblins' priestess - she, too, is a True Soul. I have not seen this druid, but he harbours worshippers of a false god in a hidden grove nearby. I intend to find it, and destroy it. Enough. Speak only to me, True Soul. The hunt must begin.
Player: Nothing makes the blood hotter. Let's hunt.
Nightwarden Minthara: Yes, sister. Together, we shall burn it to the ground. And when we destroy the trappings of this false god, the Absolute will reward us with such power.
Player: The prisoner talked, with a little encouragement. I know where the others are hiding.
Nightwarden Minthara: Tell me what you know. The Absolute will reward us with such power if we find this place.
Player: Point to the location of the grove on her map.
Nightwarden Minthara: So close! Their fate is sealed - and you will be instrumental in the slaughter. Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: They'll die thinking I'm their hero.
Nightwarden Minthara: Exquisite. The Absolute chose well when She chose you. I will gather a raiding party and move into position. You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike. We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name. And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: I've done enough. The battle is yours to fight.
Nightwarden Minthara: I do not intend to lead a suicidal charge. The goblins are expendable; I am not. The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: If I do this, I expect to be rewarded.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: I thought I smelled a Sel√ªnite.
Isobel: At your service. Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle. But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I'm glad you've remembered who needs whose help here.
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I am already protected. My Lady shields me from the curse.
Isobel: For now, perhaps. But Shar can be fickle, and her love can prove fleeting. Do not turn your back on an advantage you may need... even a Sel√ªnite one. If nothing else, it can aid any companions who travel with you - somehow I doubt Shar's largesse was extended to them.
Player: Silently petition Lady Shar for guidance.
Narrator: *She offers you nothing.*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance. This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is. Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: The Dark Lady's works aren't for me to question.
Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we? I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Nightwarden Minthara: I have been expecting you. The goblins tell me that you forced a confession from our prisoner. Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood.
Narrator: *Her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
Nightwarden Minthara: You are a True Soul, jaluk? Perhaps you are worthy to assist me. It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall.
Narrator: *You attune your mind to it. The artefact does not want to part from you. It does not want to fall into the Absolute's clutches.* *Her mind focuses - the cultists cannot discover that the weapon they seek is within their grasp.* *The drow's mind closes around yours, her bloodlust like needles in your skull.*
Player: Perhaps you can misdirect her... or kill her.
Nightwarden Minthara: My patience wears thin, True Soul. The hunt must begin. Show me the grove. Be my eyes.
Narrator: *Images of the battle at the gate shimmer into view, along with the adventurers pleading to be let inside.* *Tiefling faces flicker into view as she attempts to learn the grove's location.*
Player: Get out of my mind.
Nightwarden Minthara: Destroying this place is the Absolute's will. Would you defy Her?
Player: Open your mind to her.
Narrator: *She sees the entrance to the grove as the adventurers retreat inside, joining the tieflings...* *...and then smiles serenely as blood and shadow spread like stains across your memory, erasing all that live there.*
Nightwarden Minthara: The cowards found refuge among the desperate. Perfect. If the inhabitants do not realise you are the knife at their throats, we can use that against them. Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: And once I'm inside?
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position. You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike. We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name. And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: It shall be so.

Narrator: *Every scrap of your marrow yearns to end her. Dooming the village would bring foul glory. You can almost taste it.* *This is the one Sceleritas sent you to kill. Every scrap of your marrow yearns to end her.*
Isobel: On with you. Unless you want to come back to a gaggle of shadow-cursed Harpers.
Player: I won't let that happen.
Isobel: I know you won't. Don't let Jaheira catch you dawdling.
Narrator: *There is something about her... it would be wonderful to kill her. A perfect tragedy.*
Player: My blood... it's telling me to kill you.
Isobel: And yet you hesitate.
Narrator: *She doesn't believe you will do it. You can see, she wants to believe there is mercy in all, even in the worst.*
Isobel: You aren't the first to threaten me. But I know the eyes of a killer when I see them. You mean me no harm. Do you? An experienced cleric can tell such things.
Narrator: *The Urge within does not want to talk. The restless Urge starts to scream.*
Player: Chase away your putrid desires.
Narrator: *As suddenly as it started, you have tamed the Urge. It slumbers again.*
Isobel: There we are. The real you. Your - affliction, is it? - doesn't rule you, does it.
Player: I'm cursed with spells of madness, forgive me what I said.
Isobel: Why don't we try again, then? Who are you? Hold - who are you, and what are you doing here?
Narrator: *Your body yearns to kill this cleric, more than anything else. You know it, deep down, in your writhing intestines.*
Player: My blood... it's telling me to kill you.
Isobel: And yet you hesitate.
Narrator: *She doesn't believe you will do it. You can see, she wants to believe there is mercy in all, even in the worst.*

Narrator: *Your body yearns to kill this cleric, more than anything else. You know it, deep down, in your writhing intestines.*
Player: Attack her. The Urge aches for it.

Gale: Look at that. We're channelling the Weave. How does it feel? You did it. You're channelling the Weave. How does it feel?
Player: It's not quite like praying to her. She feels closer, somehow.
Gale: Quite so. The Weave is a sensitive conduit.
Narrator: *The Weave connects you. The moment feels intimate.*
Player: Hold on to the moment. It's a good night for intimacy.
Narrator: *You realise the Weave is making you one. You have but to imagine your desire, and Gale will know it.*
Player: Picture his severed head on a spike.

Narrator: *Every scrap of your marrow yearns to end her. Dooming the village would bring foul glory. You can almost taste it.* *This is the one Sceleritas sent you to kill. Every scrap of your marrow yearns to end her.*
Isobel: Don't let Jaheira catch you dawdling.
Narrator: *There is something about her... it would be wonderful to kill her. A perfect tragedy.*
Player: My blood... it's telling me to kill you.
Isobel: And yet you hesitate.
Narrator: *She doesn't believe you will do it. You can see, she wants to believe there is mercy in all, even in the worst.*
Isobel: You aren't the first to threaten me. But I know the eyes of a killer when I see them. You mean me no harm. Do you? An experienced cleric can tell such things.
Narrator: *The Urge within does not want to talk. The restless Urge starts to scream.*
Player: Chase away your putrid desires.
Narrator: *As suddenly as it started, you have tamed the Urge. It slumbers again.*
Isobel: There we are. The real you. Your - affliction, is it? - doesn't rule you, does it.
Player: I'm cursed with spells of madness, forgive me what I said.
Isobel: Why don't we try again, then? Who are you? Hold - who are you, and what are you doing here?
Narrator: *Your body yearns to kill this cleric, more than anything else. You know it, deep down, in your writhing intestines.*
Player: My blood... it's telling me to kill you.
Isobel: And yet you hesitate.
Narrator: *She doesn't believe you will do it. You can see, she wants to believe there is mercy in all, even in the worst.*
Isobel: You aren't the first to threaten me. But I know the eyes of a killer when I see them. You mean me no harm. Do you? An experienced cleric can tell such things.
Narrator: *The Urge within does not want to talk. The restless Urge starts to scream.*
Player: Chase away your putrid desires.
Narrator: *As suddenly as it started, you have tamed the Urge. It slumbers again.*
Isobel: There we are. The real you. Your - affliction, is it? - doesn't rule you, does it.
Player: I'm cursed with spells of madness, forgive me what I said.
Isobel: Why don't we try again, then? Who are you? Hold - who are you, and what are you doing here?
Narrator: *Your body yearns to kill this cleric, more than anything else. You know it, deep down, in your writhing intestines.*
Player: I'm [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53]. I mean you no harm.
Isobel: You'd be a bit late to the party if you did. Ketheric Thorm done for. Or didn't you see that angel carving a path straight toward Moonrise Towers?
Player: Attack her. The Urge aches for it.

Fist Marcus: Thanks for the introduction.
Isobel: Not a step closer, Marcus. I'm warning you.
Fist Marcus: I don't know what your game is, but you can still redeem yourself if you follow my lead.

NodeContext: Anger in his voice.
Fist Marcus: Remember: Ketheric wants her alive. Let's do this. Remember: Ketheric wants her alive.
Isobel: What the hells is going on?
NodeContext: SArcasm and fury in her voice as she enters battle position.
Player: Probe his thoughts for more information.
Narrator: *A haunting face swims into your mind's eye, its instructions vivid in your mind: nothing is more important than bringing the girl - alive.*
Isobel: What's going on? If you have something to say, say it.
Player: You're going to meet Ketheric - face-to-face.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale holds out his arm. Above the palm of his hand is conjured in gold-coloured magic the image of a woman, the goddess Mystra. He's looking at the figure intensely.
Player: Pretty.
Gale: Oh! My, you startled me. I... I was miles away.
NodeContext: Gale is looking at a miniature magical projection of Mystra he's created in his hand in his hand. Startled, he dispells it.
Player: Is everything all right?
Gale: Of course, of course. I was just... practising an incantation.
Player: If you say so.
Gale: I do - because it's through practice that I seek to perfect. To augment. Magic is... my life. I've been in touch with the Weave for as long as I can remember. There's nothing like it. It's like music, poetry, physical beauty all rolled into one and given expression through the senses. That is why I asked you to seek me out, to offer you a taste of such wonders. Would you like me to show you? Would you like to experience this?
Player: Yes, I would.
Gale: Then follow my lead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale walks around behind the player (as though teaching them to fly a kite) and makes a delicate gesture with both hands.
Gale: Now you.
Player: Imitate the gesture with a flourish.
Narrator: *You feel something strange - like a kind word and a kind touch at the same time. It's warm and comfortable.*
Gale: Excellent. Now repeat after me: Ah-Thran Mystra-Ryl Kantrach-Ao.
Player: An easy incantation. Simply repeat after Gale.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The visual effect intensifies. There‚Äôs the start of a glow, of a rush of beautiful magic.
Narrator: *Ah, yes: the scent of rosewater and a sense of wellbeing. A sliver of Weave that tastes sweet on the tongue.*
Gale: Very good. Now I want you to picture in your mind the concept of harmony. As true as you can.
Player: Still your mind. Focus on Mystra's grace. Her power. The peace you find in following her wisdom.

Nightwarden Minthara: The goblins tell me that you extracted a confession from our prisoner, True Soul. Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood.
Narrator: *Her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
Nightwarden Minthara: You are a True Soul? Little wonder that you serve me so well. It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall.
Narrator: *You attune your mind to it. The artefact does not want to part from you. It does not want to fall into the Absolute's clutches.* *Her mind focuses - the cultists cannot discover that the weapon they seek is within their grasp.* *The drow's mind closes around yours, her bloodlust like needles in your skull.*
Player: The tieflings should be warned. Together, you can outnumber her warband.
Nightwarden Minthara: My patience wears thin, True Soul. The hunt must begin. Show me the grove. Be my eyes.
Narrator: *Images of the battle at the gate shimmer into view, along with the adventurers pleading to be let inside.* *Tiefling faces flicker into view as she attempts to learn the grove's location.*
Player: Allow her to read your thoughts.
Narrator: *She sees the entrance to the grove as the adventurers retreat inside, joining the tieflings...* *...and then smiles serenely as blood and shadow spread like stains across your memory, erasing all that live there.*
Nightwarden Minthara: The cowards found refuge among the desperate. Perfect. If the inhabitants do not realise you are the knife at their throats, we can use that against them. Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: They'll die thinking I'm their hero.
Nightwarden Minthara: Exquisite. The Absolute chose well when She chose you. I will gather a raiding party and move into position. You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike. We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name. And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: Reject these dreams of a bloodbath.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: If I do this, I expect to be rewarded.

Isobel: There we are. The real you. Your - affliction, is it? - doesn't rule you, does it.
Player: I won't harm you... I don't know what came over me.
Isobel: Why don't we try again, then? Who are you? Hold - who are you, and what are you doing here?
Narrator: *Your body yearns to kill this cleric, more than anything else. You know it, deep down, in your writhing intestines.*
Player: Attack her. The Urge aches for it.

Nightwarden Minthara: I do not have time for interruptions, sister.
Narrator: *As she turns to you, her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
NodeContext: unnerved
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player sees a vision of Minthara with Orin, one of the Absolute's chosen.
InternalNodeContext: Cinematic blocked until Orin asset/voice available. Cinematic blocked until Orin asset/voice available.
Nightwarden Minthara: A True Soul? Praise be, sister. Are you here to join my hunt? Her heart is more generous than mine. Join my hunt, faerie. And obey me.
Player: I'm on a hunt of my own. I'm looking for a druid named Halsin.
Nightwarden Minthara: Interesting. What do you know of this druid?
Player: I visited his grove.
Nightwarden Minthara: Perfect. This grove is the place I am seeking. Show me where it is, and we will destroy it together. There is a weapon the Absolute seeks - I'm sure those wretches have it hidden away there. We will find it, amongst the dead and the ashes.
Narrator: *Her excitement is palpable. She lingers on thoughts of victory, of unbelievers' blood spilled...* *...and of the weapon. She will seize it, in the Absolute's name.* *You realise that the weapon the drow's mind dwells upon is the gith artefact you carry. You cannot let her discover it - no matter what.* *Her mind focuses - the cultists cannot discover that the weapon they seek is within their grasp.*
Nightwarden Minthara: Show me the grove. Be my eyes.
Narrator: *Images of the battle at the gate shimmer into view, along with the adventurers pleading to be let inside.* *Tiefling faces flicker into view as she attempts to learn the grove's location.*
Player: Allow her to read your thoughts.
Narrator: *She sees the entrance to the grove as the adventurers retreat inside, joining the tieflings...* *...and then smiles serenely as blood and shadow spread like stains across your memory, erasing all that live there.*
Nightwarden Minthara: The cowards found refuge among the desperate. Perfect. If the inhabitants do not realise you are the knife at their throats, we can use that against them. Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: And once I'm inside?
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position. You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike. We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name. And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: It shall be so.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale holds out his arm. Above the palm of his hand is conjured in gold-coloured magic the image of a woman, the goddess Mystra. He's looking at the figure intensely.
Player: Pretty.
Gale: Oh! My, you startled me. I... I was miles away.
NodeContext: Gale is looking at a miniature magical projection of Mystra he's created in his hand in his hand. Startled, he dispells it.
Player: Is everything all right?
Gale: Of course, of course. I was just... practising an incantation.
Player: There's more to it than that. The figure I saw: she means something to you.
Gale: She does. She's... She's Mystra. I can't quite describe it, the need I sometimes feel to see her - to draw the filaments of fantasy into existence. No sculpture or painting could ever do her justice, only the fabric that she herself is and embodies: The Weave. Mystra is all magic. And as far as I'm concerned, she is all creation.
Player: I didn't realise the depth of your devotion.
Gale: Magic is... my life. I've been in touch with the Weave for as long as I can remember. There's nothing like it. It's like music, poetry, physical beauty all rolled into one and given expression through the senses. Would you like to experience this?
Player: Yes, I would.
Gale: Then follow my lead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale walks around behind the player (as though teaching them to fly a kite) and makes a delicate gesture with both hands.
Gale: Now you.
Player: Imitate the gesture slowly and as precisely as you can.
Narrator: *You feel something strange - like a kind word and a kind touch at the same time. It's warm and comfortable.*
Gale: Excellent. Now repeat after me: Ah-Thran Mystra-Ryl Kantrach-Ao.
Player: You sense power in these words. Speak them deliberately.
Narrator: *Suddenly: the scent of rosewater and a sense of wellbeing. A sliver of Weave that tastes sweet on the tongue.*
Gale: Very good. Now I want you to picture in your mind the concept of harmony. As true as you can.
Player: Sink deep into your magic. It is who you are. It is home.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The player and Gale are now fully enveloped in a magic glow - a protective field of beautiful magic. Unconsciously player steps back closer to Gale.
Narrator: *You see - or is it sense? - the unmistakable presence of Mystra, the Lady of Mysteries.* *There's something like the anticipation of a kiss, then the pleasure of being cloaked in peace.* *You are safe. You are nestled in the cup of her hand.*
Gale: You did it. You're channelling the Weave. How does it feel?
Player: It's different, but I can definitely feel Mystra's presence.
Gale: Quite so. The Weave is a sensitive conduit.
Narrator: *The Weave connects you. The moment feels intimate.*
Player: Hold on to the moment. It's a good night for intimacy.
Narrator: *You realise the Weave is making you one. You have but to imagine your desire, and Gale will know it.*
Player: Picture kicking him in the gut.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down. Isobel - Isobel Thorm?
Isobel: An unfortunate coincidence. I hope never to meet the wicked man who haemorrhaged shadows over this peaceful village. I've heard you might be the person to stop him. A True Soul with a soul. Imagine. But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I'm glad you've remembered who needs whose help here.
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I am already protected. My Lady shields me from the curse.
Isobel: For now, perhaps. But Shar can be fickle, and her love can prove fleeting. Do not turn your back on an advantage you may need... even a Sel√ªnite one. If nothing else, it can aid any companions who travel with you - somehow I doubt Shar's largesse was extended to them.
Player: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance. This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is. Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: That's none of your concern.
Isobel: I suppose you're right. I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Player: Give Gale a magic artefact.
Gale: My condition requires a delicate touch. Just one item will suffice to keep it in check.
Player: Understood. I'll give you what you need.
Gale: My condition requires a delicate touch. Just one item will suffice to keep it in check.
Player: Understood. I'll give you what you need.
Gale: Perhaps I'm not conveying the urgency of the situation. It's incredibly, world-shatteringly important you give me a suitable artefact. Please.
Player: Give Gale a suitable artefact.
Gale: My condition requires a delicate touch. Just one item will suffice to keep it in check.
Player: Understood. I'll give you what you need.
Gale: My condition requires a delicate touch. Just one item will suffice to keep it in check.

Gale: Perhaps I'm not conveying the urgency of the situation. It's incredibly, world-shatteringly important you give me a suitable artefact. Please.
Player: I'm not giving you anything. Not now, not ever.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The visual effect intensifies. There‚Äôs the start of a glow, of a rush of beautiful magic.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The player and Gale are now fully enveloped in a magic glow - a protective field of beautiful magic. Unconsciously player steps back closer to Gale.

Isobel: What's on your mind? Don't let Jaheira catch you dawdling.

Player: My blood... it's telling me to kill you.
Isobel: And yet you hesitate.
Narrator: *She doesn't believe you will do it. You can see, she wants to believe there is mercy in all, even in the worst.*
Isobel: You aren't the first to threaten me. But I know the eyes of a killer when I see them. You mean me no harm. Do you? An experienced cleric can tell such things.
Narrator: *The Urge within does not want to talk. The restless Urge starts to scream.*

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down. I thought I smelled a Sel√ªnite.
Isobel: At your service. Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle. But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I may have the parasite of a True Soul, but not the mind of one.
Isobel: And that's what makes you essential. You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume? Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I am already protected. My Lady shields me from the curse.
Isobel: For now, perhaps. But Shar can be fickle, and her love can prove fleeting. Do not turn your back on an advantage you may need... even a Sel√ªnite one. If nothing else, it can aid any companions who travel with you - somehow I doubt Shar's largesse was extended to them.
Player: It was nothing. Put it out of your mind.
Narrator: *But was it truly nothing? The pain gripped you tight, robbing you of all composure for a moment...*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance. This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is. Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: I don't know what to make of it myself.
Isobel: I suppose Shar is nothing if not mysterious. I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I've already been to Moonrise, but I have more work to do indeed.
Isobel: I imagine so, if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing off into the night.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Nightwarden Minthara: I do not have time for interruptions from underlings.
Narrator: *As she turns to you, her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
NodeContext: unnerved
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player sees a vision of Minthara with Orin, one of the Absolute's chosen.
InternalNodeContext: Cinematic blocked until Orin asset/voice available. Cinematic blocked until Orin asset/voice available.
Nightwarden Minthara: A True Soul? Praise be, sister. Are you here to join my hunt? Her heart is more generous than mine. Join my hunt, faerie. And obey me.
Player: I'm on a hunt of my own. I'm looking for a druid named Halsin.
Nightwarden Minthara: Interesting. What do you know of this druid?
Player: I visited his grove.
Nightwarden Minthara: Perfect. This grove is the place I am seeking. Show me where it is, and we will destroy it together. There is a weapon the Absolute seeks - I'm sure those wretches have it hidden away there. We will find it, amongst the dead and the ashes.
Narrator: *Her excitement is palpable. She lingers on thoughts of victory, of unbelievers' blood spilled...* *...and of the weapon. She will seize it, in the Absolute's name.* *The drow's mind closes around yours, her bloodlust like needles in your skull.*
Player: The tieflings should be warned. Together, you can outnumber her warband.
Nightwarden Minthara: My patience wears thin, True Soul. The hunt must begin. Show me the grove. Be my eyes.
Narrator: *Images of the battle at the gate shimmer into view, along with the adventurers pleading to be let inside.* *Tiefling faces flicker into view as she attempts to learn the grove's location.*
Player: Allow her to read your thoughts.
Narrator: *She sees the entrance to the grove as the adventurers retreat inside, joining the tieflings...* *...and then smiles serenely as blood and shadow spread like stains across your memory, erasing all that live there.*
Nightwarden Minthara: The cowards found refuge among the desperate. Perfect. If the inhabitants do not realise you are the knife at their throats, we can use that against them. Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: I prefer to face my enemies rather than stabbing them in the back.
Nightwarden Minthara: How noble. I prefer to win. I will gather a raiding party and move into position. You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike. We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name. And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: It shall be so.

Narrator: *You see - or is it sense? - the presence of a woman, the woman who hovered over Gale's palm.* *There's something like the anticipation of a kiss, then the pleasure of being cloaked in peace.* *You are safe. You are nestled in the cup of her hand.*
Gale: You did it. You're channelling the Weave. How does it feel?
Player: It's different, but I can definitely feel Mystra's presence.
Gale: Quite so. The Weave is a sensitive conduit.
Narrator: *The Weave connects you. The moment feels intimate.*
Player: Hold on to the moment. It's a good night for intimacy.
Narrator: *You realise the Weave is making you one. You have but to imagine your desire, and Gale will know it.*
Player: Picture his severed head on a spike.

Nightwarden Minthara: I have been expecting you. The goblins tell me that you forced a confession from our prisoner. Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood. You serve the Absolute well. It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall.
Narrator: *You attune your mind to it. The artefact does not want to part from you. It does not want to fall into the Absolute's clutches.* *Her mind focuses - the cultists cannot discover that the weapon they seek is within their grasp.* *The drow's mind closes around yours, her bloodlust like needles in your skull.*
Player: Leading her to the tieflings might doom them... but it would earn her trust.
Nightwarden Minthara: My patience wears thin, True Soul. The hunt must begin. Show me the grove. Be my eyes.
Narrator: *Images of the battle at the gate shimmer into view, along with the adventurers pleading to be let inside.* *Tiefling faces flicker into view as she attempts to learn the grove's location.*
Player: Get out of my mind.
Nightwarden Minthara: Destroying this place is the Absolute's will. Would you defy Her?
Player: Open your mind to her.
Narrator: *She sees the entrance to the grove as the adventurers retreat inside, joining the tieflings...* *...and then smiles serenely as blood and shadow spread like stains across your memory, erasing all that live there.*
Nightwarden Minthara: The cowards found refuge among the desperate. Perfect. If the inhabitants do not realise you are the knife at their throats, we can use that against them. Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: And once I'm inside?
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position. You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike. We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name. And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: I've done enough. The battle is yours to fight.
Nightwarden Minthara: I do not intend to lead a suicidal charge. The goblins are expendable; I am not. The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: You're right. I'll see you at the grove.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale holds out his arm. Above the palm of his hand is conjured in gold-coloured magic the image of a woman, the goddess Mystra. He's looking at the figure intensely.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down. Isobel - Isobel Thorm?
Narrator: *Her breath catches; you notice a barely-perceptible shudder run through her body.*
Isobel: An unfortunate coincidence. I hope never to meet the wicked man who haemorrhaged shadows over this peaceful village. I've heard you might be the person to stop him. A True Soul with a soul. Imagine. But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: You seem to have a lot to say about my allegiance. Can we focus on the task at hand?
Isobel: I suppose that would be wise. We have a common enemy, after all: Ketheric Thorm. You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume? Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I need nothing from a Sel√ªnite.
Isobel: But any others who travel with you may not agree. Do it for them at least - you will need all the help you can get out there.
Narrator: *Pain bursts from the wound on your hand. You see yourself kneeling in a dark hall, surrounded by initiates. A female voice preaches against Sel√ªne and all she stands for. You nod, rapt.*
InternalNodeContext: Incurable wound imagery/memoriy fragment
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance. This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is. Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: I don't know what to make of it myself.
Isobel: I suppose Shar is nothing if not mysterious. I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Narrator: *Your body yearns to kill this cleric, more than anything else. You know it, deep down, in your writhing intestines.*
Player: My blood... it's telling me to kill you.
Isobel: And yet you hesitate.
Narrator: *She doesn't believe you will do it. You can see, she wants to believe there is mercy in all, even in the worst.*
Isobel: You aren't the first to threaten me. But I know the eyes of a killer when I see them. You mean me no harm. Do you? An experienced cleric can tell such things.
Narrator: *The Urge within does not want to talk. The restless Urge starts to scream.*
Player: Chase away your putrid desires.
Narrator: *As suddenly as it started, you have tamed the Urge. It slumbers again.*

Nightwarden Minthara: I have been expecting you. The goblins tell me that you forced a confession from our prisoner. Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood. You serve the Absolute well. It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall.
Narrator: *You attune your mind to it. The artefact does not want to part from you. It does not want to fall into the Absolute's clutches.* *Her mind focuses - the cultists cannot discover that the weapon they seek is within their grasp.* *The drow's mind closes around yours, her bloodlust like needles in your skull.*
Player: Even with the grove's numbers depleted, dealing with her there may be safer than fighting here.
Nightwarden Minthara: My patience wears thin, True Soul. The hunt must begin. Show me the grove. Be my eyes.
Narrator: *Images of the battle at the gate shimmer into view, along with the adventurers pleading to be let inside.* *Tiefling faces flicker into view as she attempts to learn the grove's location.*
Player: Get out of my mind.
Nightwarden Minthara: Destroying this place is the Absolute's will. Would you defy Her?
Player: Open your mind to her.
Narrator: *She sees the entrance to the grove as the adventurers retreat inside, joining the tieflings...* *...and then smiles serenely as blood and shadow spread like stains across your memory, erasing all that live there.*
Nightwarden Minthara: The cowards found refuge among the desperate. Perfect. If the inhabitants do not realise you are the knife at their throats, we can use that against them. Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: I prefer to face my enemies rather than stabbing them in the back.
Nightwarden Minthara: How noble. I prefer to win. I will gather a raiding party and move into position. You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike. We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name. And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: Reject these dreams of a bloodbath.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: You're right. I'll see you at the grove.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -

Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*

Isobel: At your service. Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle. But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I may have the parasite of a True Soul, but not the mind of one.
Isobel: And that's what makes you essential. You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume? Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?

Player: The Dark Lady's works aren't for me to question.
Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we? I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I've already been to Moonrise, but I have more work to do indeed.
Isobel: I imagine so, if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing off into the night.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale holds out his arm. Above the palm of his hand is conjured in gold-coloured magic the image of a woman, the goddess Mystra. He's looking at the figure intensely.
Player: Pretty.
Gale: Oh! My, you startled me. I... I was miles away.
NodeContext: Gale is looking at a miniature magical projection of Mystra he's created in his hand in his hand. Startled, he dispells it.
Player: Is everything all right?
Gale: Of course, of course. I was just... practising an incantation.
Player: There's more to it than that. The figure I saw: she means something to you.
Gale: She does. She's... She's Mystra. I can't quite describe it, the need I sometimes feel to see her - to draw the filaments of fantasy into existence. No sculpture or painting could ever do her justice, only the fabric that she herself is and embodies: The Weave. Mystra is all magic. And as far as I'm concerned, she is all creation.
Player: Sounding more of a poet than a wizard there, Gale.
Gale: It's a kind of love after all. Magic is... my life. I've been in touch with the Weave for as long as I can remember. There's nothing like it. It's like music, poetry, physical beauty all rolled into one and given expression through the senses. Would you like to experience this?
Player: Yes, I would.
Gale: Then follow my lead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale walks around behind the player (as though teaching them to fly a kite) and makes a delicate gesture with both hands.
Gale: Now you.
Player: Imitate the gesture with a flourish.
Narrator: *You feel something strange - like a kind word and a kind touch at the same time. It's warm and comfortable.*
Gale: Excellent. Now repeat after me: Ah-Thran Mystra-Ryl Kantrach-Ao.
Player: An easy incantation. Simply repeat after Gale.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The visual effect intensifies. There‚Äôs the start of a glow, of a rush of beautiful magic.
Narrator: *Ah, yes: the scent of rosewater and a sense of wellbeing. A sliver of Weave that tastes sweet on the tongue.*
Gale: Very good. Now I want you to picture in your mind the concept of harmony. As true as you can.
Player: Harmony comes easily to you. Allow it to wash over your mind and magic.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The player and Gale are now fully enveloped in a magic glow - a protective field of beautiful magic. Unconsciously player steps back closer to Gale.
Narrator: *You see - or is it sense? - the unmistakable presence of Mystra, the Lady of Mysteries.* *There's something like the anticipation of a kiss, then the pleasure of being cloaked in peace.* *You are safe. You are nestled in the cup of her hand.*
Gale: You did it. You're channelling the Weave. How does it feel?
Player: It's different, but I can definitely feel Mystra's presence.
Gale: Quite so. The Weave is a sensitive conduit.
Narrator: *The Weave connects you. The moment feels intimate.*
Player: Hold on to the moment. It's a good night for intimacy.
Narrator: *You realise the Weave is making you one. You have but to imagine your desire, and Gale will know it.*
Player: Picture kicking him in the gut.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Wait! Argh. Wait just a tick. Killing me is a waste of time - I'll find a way to return. Always have, always will. But it's... unpleasant. So how about we be civilised about this, hmm? I have something you want.
Player: What I want is Mayrina - alive and free.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: But she's worthless to you!
Mayrina: Don't let her take me. Please.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Shut it. You owe me a babe, girl. And I'll take it - whether you like it or not. Let me leave with the girl, and I'll give you power. You want to be stronger? Tougher? Smarter? Done! Anything is possible. (Ability Score +1) Just let me keep the girl and her babe.
Lae'zel: A simple trade? More deception. Take her head.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: It's your choice, sweetness.
Player: If you want to live, hand over Mayrina and this power. Right now.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Not a hope. It's one or the other.
Player: Keep the girl. I'll take the power.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down. Isobel - Isobel Thorm?
Isobel: An unfortunate coincidence. I hope never to meet the wicked man who haemorrhaged shadows over this peaceful village. I've heard you might be the person to stop him. A True Soul with a soul. Imagine. But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I won't be spoken to like that by a Sel√ªnite.
Isobel: We've both got a bitter pill to swallow. When this is all over, we can spit it back out. You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume? Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I need nothing from a Sel√ªnite.
Isobel: But any others who travel with you may not agree. Do it for them at least - you will need all the help you can get out there.
Player: It was nothing. Put it out of your mind.
Narrator: *But was it truly nothing? The pain gripped you tight, robbing you of all composure for a moment...*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance. This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is. Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: That's none of your concern.
Isobel: I suppose you're right. I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I've already been to Moonrise, but I have more work to do indeed.
Isobel: I imagine so, if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing off into the night.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Nightwarden Minthara: The goblins tell me that you extracted a confession from our prisoner, True Soul. Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood.
Narrator: *Her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
Nightwarden Minthara: You are a True Soul, sister? It is good to have your assistance. It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall. Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: And once I'm inside?
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position. You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike. We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name. And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: Reject these dreams of a bloodbath.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: You're right. I'll see you at the grove.

Nightwarden Minthara: The goblins tell me that you extracted a confession from our prisoner, True Soul. Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood. You serve the Absolute well. It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall.
Narrator: *You attune your mind to it. The artefact does not want to part from you. It does not want to fall into the Absolute's clutches.* *Her mind focuses - the cultists cannot discover that the weapon they seek is within their grasp.* *The drow's mind closes around yours, her bloodlust like needles in your skull.*
Player: The grove's inhabitants are weak - it's ready to fall.
Nightwarden Minthara: My patience wears thin, True Soul. The hunt must begin. Show me the grove. Be my eyes.
Narrator: *Images of the battle at the gate shimmer into view, along with the adventurers pleading to be let inside.* *Tiefling faces flicker into view as she attempts to learn the grove's location.*
Player: Allow her to read your thoughts.
Narrator: *She sees the entrance to the grove as the adventurers retreat inside, joining the tieflings...* *...and then smiles serenely as blood and shadow spread like stains across your memory, erasing all that live there.*
Nightwarden Minthara: The cowards found refuge among the desperate. Perfect. If the inhabitants do not realise you are the knife at their throats, we can use that against them. Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: They'll die thinking I'm their hero.
Nightwarden Minthara: Exquisite. The Absolute chose well when She chose you. I will gather a raiding party and move into position. You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike. We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name. And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: I've done enough. The battle is yours to fight.
Nightwarden Minthara: I do not intend to lead a suicidal charge. The goblins are expendable; I am not. The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: If I do this, I expect to be rewarded.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale holds out his arm. Above the palm of his hand is conjured in gold-coloured magic the image of a woman, the goddess Mystra. He's looking at the figure intensely.
Player: Pretty.
Gale: Oh! My, you startled me. I... I was miles away.
NodeContext: Gale is looking at a miniature magical projection of Mystra he's created in his hand in his hand. Startled, he dispells it.
Player: Is everything all right?
Gale: Of course, of course. I was just... practising an incantation.
Player: There's more to it than that. The figure I saw: she means something to you.
Gale: She does. She's... She's Mystra. I can't quite describe it, the need I sometimes feel to see her - to draw the filaments of fantasy into existence. No sculpture or painting could ever do her justice, only the fabric that she herself is and embodies: The Weave. Mystra is all magic. And as far as I'm concerned, she is all creation.
Player: I didn't realise the depth of your devotion.
Gale: Magic is... my life. I've been in touch with the Weave for as long as I can remember. There's nothing like it. It's like music, poetry, physical beauty all rolled into one and given expression through the senses. Would you like to experience this?
Player: Yes, I would.
Gale: Then follow my lead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale walks around behind the player (as though teaching them to fly a kite) and makes a delicate gesture with both hands.
Gale: Now you.
Player: Imitate the gesture with a flourish.
Narrator: *You feel something strange - like a kind word and a kind touch at the same time. It's warm and comfortable.*
Gale: Excellent. Now repeat after me: Ah-Thran Mystra-Ryl Kantrach-Ao.
Player: An easy incantation. Simply repeat after Gale.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The visual effect intensifies. There‚Äôs the start of a glow, of a rush of beautiful magic.
Narrator: *Ah, yes: the scent of rosewater and a sense of wellbeing. A sliver of Weave that tastes sweet on the tongue.*
Gale: Very good. Now I want you to picture in your mind the concept of harmony. As true as you can.
Player: Recede into the calm centre of your mind, just like you were taught at the academy.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The player and Gale are now fully enveloped in a magic glow - a protective field of beautiful magic. Unconsciously player steps back closer to Gale.
Narrator: *You see - or is it sense? - the unmistakable presence of Mystra, the Lady of Mysteries.* *There's something like the anticipation of a kiss, then the pleasure of being cloaked in peace.* *You are safe. You are nestled in the cup of her hand.*
Gale: You did it. You're channelling the Weave. How does it feel?
Player: It's different, but I can definitely feel Mystra's presence.
Gale: Quite so. The Weave is a sensitive conduit.
Narrator: *The Weave connects you. The moment feels intimate.*
Player: Hold on to the moment. It's a good night for intimacy.
Narrator: *You realise the Weave is making you one. You have but to imagine your desire, and Gale will know it.*
Player: Picture his severed head on a spike.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down. You can tell my allegiance from a look?
Isobel: It's an aura. Or a lack of one, really. Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle. But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I won't be spoken to like that by a Sel√ªnite.
Isobel: We've both got a bitter pill to swallow. When this is all over, we can spit it back out. You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume? Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: Nod. Better to humour her than make an enemy of all in this place. Lady Shar will understand.
Isobel: Refreshingly pragmatic of you. I sense Shar has offered some amount of protection to you already, but... well, no harm in extra precaution - even from a Sel√ªnite.
Player: It was nothing. Put it out of your mind.
Narrator: *But was it truly nothing? The pain gripped you tight, robbing you of all composure for a moment...*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance. This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is. Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: That's none of your concern.
Isobel: I suppose you're right. I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I've already been to Moonrise, but I have more work to do indeed.
Isobel: I imagine so, if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing off into the night.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale holds out his arm. Above the palm of his hand is conjured in gold-coloured magic the image of a woman, the goddess Mystra. He's looking at the figure intensely.
Player: Pretty.
Gale: Oh! My, you startled me. I... I was miles away.
NodeContext: Gale is looking at a miniature magical projection of Mystra he's created in his hand in his hand. Startled, he dispells it.
Player: Is everything all right?
Gale: Of course, of course. I was just... practising an incantation.
Player: There's more to it than that. The figure I saw: she means something to you.
Gale: She does. She's... She's Mystra. I can't quite describe it, the need I sometimes feel to see her - to draw the filaments of fantasy into existence. No sculpture or painting could ever do her justice, only the fabric that she herself is and embodies: The Weave. Mystra is all magic. And as far as I'm concerned, she is all creation.
Player: Sounding more of a poet than a wizard there, Gale.
Gale: It's a kind of love after all. Magic is... my life. I've been in touch with the Weave for as long as I can remember. There's nothing like it. It's like music, poetry, physical beauty all rolled into one and given expression through the senses. Would you like to experience this?
Player: Magic normally comes to me through prayer, but I don't mind trying.
Gale: Then follow my lead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale walks around behind the player (as though teaching them to fly a kite) and makes a delicate gesture with both hands.
Gale: Now you.
Player: Imitate the gesture with a flourish.
Narrator: *You feel something strange - like a kind word and a kind touch at the same time. It's warm and comfortable.*
Gale: Excellent. Now repeat after me: Ah-Thran Mystra-Ryl Kantrach-Ao.
Player: You sense power in these words. Speak them deliberately.
Narrator: *Suddenly: the scent of rosewater and a sense of wellbeing. A sliver of Weave that tastes sweet on the tongue.*
Gale: Very good. Now I want you to picture in your mind the concept of harmony. As true as you can.
Player: Sink deep into your magic. It is who you are. It is home.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The player and Gale are now fully enveloped in a magic glow - a protective field of beautiful magic. Unconsciously player steps back closer to Gale.
Narrator: *You see - or is it sense? - the unmistakable presence of Mystra, the Lady of Mysteries.* *There's something like the anticipation of a kiss, then the pleasure of being cloaked in peace.* *You are safe. You are nestled in the cup of her hand.*
Gale: You did it. You're channelling the Weave. How does it feel?
Player: It's different, but I can definitely feel a familiar kind of presence.
Gale: Quite so. The Weave is a sensitive conduit.
Narrator: *The Weave connects you. The moment feels intimate.*
Player: Hold on to the moment. It's a good night for intimacy.
Narrator: *You realise the Weave is making you one. You have but to imagine your desire, and Gale will know it.*
Player: Picture kicking him in the gut.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up on  the player arriving in a secluded grove.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.
Gale: I love this time of night.
NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break. The cradle of eternity. The timelessness of lovers. That most beautiful of fantasies.
Player: I'm afraid all of this is just a fantasy.
Gale: So it is. But a very fine one. This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder... ...and with company to match.
NodeContext: Full of longing
Gale: I thought this place might bring me peace. I thought it might make the weight of what I must do feel a little lighter... but I am not so sure.
Player: Are you not afraid?
Gale: Afraid? No, I am terrified. But fear or courage or reason cannot change the charge I've been given. There is no point in running from the inevitable. Better to meet it, on my own terms.
Player: You sound sure in your course of action then.
Gale: Resigned to it, rather. But that is not to say I am without fear. Far from it. Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

Narrator: *This is the one Sceleritas sent you to kill. Every scrap of your marrow yearns to end her.*
Isobel: Don't let Jaheira catch you dawdling.
Narrator: *There is something about her... it would be wonderful to kill her. A perfect tragedy.*
Player: My blood... it's telling me to kill you.
Isobel: And yet you hesitate.
Narrator: *She doesn't believe you will do it. You can see, she wants to believe there is mercy in all, even in the worst.*
Isobel: You aren't the first to threaten me. But I know the eyes of a killer when I see them. You mean me no harm. Do you? An experienced cleric can tell such things.
Narrator: *The Urge within does not want to talk. The restless Urge starts to scream.*
Player: Chase away your putrid desires.
Narrator: *As suddenly as it started, you have tamed the Urge. It slumbers again.*
Isobel: There we are. The real you. Your - affliction, is it? - doesn't rule you, does it.
Player: I'm not going to follow my order. You will live.
Isobel: Why don't we try again, then? Who are you? Hold - who are you, and what are you doing here?
Narrator: *Your body yearns to kill this cleric, more than anything else. You know it, deep down, in your writhing intestines.*
Player: Attack her. The Urge aches for it.

Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance. Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we? I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.
