[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up on  the player arriving in a secluded grove.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.
Gale: I love this time of night.
NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break. The cradle of eternity. The timelessness of lovers. That most beautiful of fantasies.
Player: I'm afraid all of this is just a fantasy.
Gale: So it is. But a very fine one. This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder... ...and with company to match.
NodeContext: Full of longing
Gale: I thought this place might bring me peace. I thought it might make the weight of what I must do feel a little lighter... but I am not so sure.
Player: It's a heavy burden, yes - but one you're able for. Think of the good your sacrifice will do.
Gale: I am trying. Believe me, I am. The path is set, and I will not stray from it - even as my heart quakes. I am terrified - I will not claim otherwise. My face could scarcely conceal it even if my words sought to deny it. There is no point in running from the inevitable. Better to meet it, on my own terms.
Player: You sound sure in your course of action then.
Gale: Resigned to it, rather. But that is not to say I am without fear. Far from it. Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

Orin: Look at it, sneaking and snivelling in the shadows.
NodeContext: Sneering, the player failed to free the victim from the altar
Orin: No trust in my promises, but I smell the tyrant's corpse-reek. You are steeped in his rot. You knew the Murder Lord could not be denied his meat. See how good I was? How patient while you drained the tyrant's juices for me? But you did not listen. Thought my instructions could be ignored. I told you what to do, whelp worm, and you disobeyed. Disobedience must be punished.
NodeContext: Whispered to the comapnion on the altar, but intended for the player. She's been punished for her own disobedience countless times before, and enjoys doling this out to others.
Orin: Did it think it could protect? Did it think it could save? Only the blades can offer salvation.
NodeContext: Hushed, as though to companion on altar, but really for player's benefit. Mocking player's intentions. On  the cusp of killing the victim. 'It' is player.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: If you're gloating now, just wait 'til you hear my offer, petal. Let me leave with the girl, and I'll give you power. You want to be stronger? Tougher? Smarter? Done! Anything is possible. (Ability Score +1) Just let me keep the girl and her babe.
Shadowheart: If her powers were worth anything, we wouldn't have beaten her. Finish this.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: It's your choice, sweetness.
Player: Such power will let me better serve the Spider Queen. Give it to me. Keep the girl. I'll take the power.

Player: You're right. At least this way, you might take the Absolute down with you.

Player: I'm not going anywhere, Gale. I'll be by your side, whatever dawn brings.

I just can't fathom what that might be, other than to fail Mystra and condemn the world. Stay with me, will you? I don't want to think of it any more, but I don't want to be alone either.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help. The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation. We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold. I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed. We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter. He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope. You are that hope.
Player: What do you have in mind?
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul. Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage. Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Jaheir takes the glass from the table.

Jaheira: A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer. But you're far from the most eccentric drinking companion I've had. I'd like to know more. Cheers. To your very good health.

Sazza: Mistress! It's me, yer loyal servant, Sazza. I'm back - an' I brought a friend.
Nightwarden Minthara: A drow? Tell me, Sazza, did your misadventures take you to the Underdark?
Sazza: They woz in some rickety druid grove! Mostly full of tieflin's, but them intruders you're after were hidin' out there!
Nightwarden Minthara: I presume you dealt with my prey, and massacred the rest?
Sazza: Ah... well, the thing about that is... they sorta massacred us. This mug helped me escape though. I say we stick a few holes in them... show how grateful we are.

Narrator: *You feel a cold hand caress your mind as the drow appraises you.*
Nightwarden Minthara: Oh dear. Your prisoner is one of the Absolute's favourites, Sazza. A True Soul.
Sazza: Nah. Can't be... they woz in the grove, hangin' around with the tieflin's.
Nightwarden Minthara: Undercover, no doubt. Carrying out the Absolute's will. Oh, Sazza - you have made a grave error. And it will be your last. My spiders are hungry, little one... ...but before they feast, tell me where that grove is, and I may yet spare your life.
Sazza: It's past the bridge, to the east! Big ol' gate, covered in ivy! Don't hurt me, mistress. Please!
Nightwarden Minthara: I will not hurt you. My spiders will have that pleasure.
Sazza: No! I mucked up, I'm sorry! But I didn't know who they woz... they didn't tell me nothin'!
Player: You only have to look at me to know I'm your superior, wretch.
Sazza: Somebody help!
Nightwarden Minthara: Through sheer luck, that pathetic worm has brought me the information I need. And it seems that the inhabitants of the grove trust you - we can use that against them. You have a part to play in this slaughter. Return to the grove. When my raiding party approaches, throw open the gate and signal me.
Narrator: *The fate of the grove's inhabitants hangs in the balance.* *Killing the drow here would spare them, but it might be better to face her warband at the grove itself, on familiar ground.* *On the other hand, participating in the slaughter as she asks may be the perfect way to earn her trust, and access to the cult's inner circle.*
Player: I'll get it done.

Gale: A word, if you please. Remember how I told you I was in dire need of magical artefacts to absorb? Clearly the matter has hardly been a priority of yours, but even so, you can consider it closed. I no longer require assistance - neither yours, nor that of artefacts.
Player: I don't follow. This seems awfully sudden.
Gale: Not at all. I've had a solution in mind for a while now, it just took me some time to... set it in motion. That's it - I won't take more of your time this lovely evening. Rest well.
Player: Something's off. Try to connect with Gale without him noticing.
Narrator: *You flutter through his mind like a bat through the night and you see...* *... fire. You hear laughter. You smell brimstone.* *It's the scent of Avernus.*
Gale: Stop that! How dare you - again... Forget whatever it was you saw. It's all beyond you now anyway.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Wait! Argh. Wait just a tick. Killing me is a waste of time - I'll find a way to return. Always have, always will. But it's... unpleasant. So how about we be civilised about this, hmm? I have something you want.
Player: What I want is Mayrina - alive and free.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: But she's worthless to you! Let me leave with the girl, and I'll give you power. You want to be stronger? Tougher? Smarter? Done! Anything is possible. (Ability Score +1) Just let me keep the girl and her babe.
Gale: Not only would this be a vile deal, it would be folly to trust a hag's gifts.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: It's your choice, sweetness.
Player: Keep the girl. I'll take the power.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up on  the player arriving in a secluded grove.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.
Gale: I love this time of night.
NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break. The cradle of eternity. The timelessness of lovers. That most beautiful of fantasies.
Player: You seem especially philosophical this evening. Are you all right?
Gale: I will be, soon. I am perhaps just one hard day away from being without any troubles at all. This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder... ...and with company to match.
NodeContext: Full of longing
Gale: I thought this place might bring me peace. I thought it might make the weight of what I must do feel a little lighter... but I am not so sure.
Player: It's a heavy burden, yes - but one you're able for. Think of the good your sacrifice will do.
Gale: I am trying. Believe me, I am. The path is set, and I will not stray from it - even as my heart quakes. I am terrified - I will not claim otherwise. My face could scarcely conceal it even if my words sought to deny it. There is no point in running from the inevitable. Better to meet it, on my own terms.
Player: You're right. At least this way, you might take the Absolute down with you.
Gale: I can only hope that there are few innocents within the Absolute's reach, when the time comes... and that you will seek safety, far away from me. Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'm not going anywhere, Gale. I'll be by your side, whatever dawn brings.
Gale: Yes... but there is so much to live for, and so few moments in which to house it all. Damn you. Damn you for giving me so much to care about. Our friends, our adventures... this would have been so much easier if it was just me. But it isn't. If there is a way - any way - to save all that's grown dear to me, I want to seize it. I just can't fathom what that might be, other than to fail Mystra and condemn the world. Stay with me, will you? I don't want to think of it any more, but I don't want to be alone either.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help. The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation. We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold. I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed. We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter. He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope. You are that hope.
Player: I'm trying my best to be...
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul. Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage. Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Jaheir takes the glass from the table.
Jaheira: This place is crawling with Harpers. If Marcus managed to get himself infected, we would've known the same minute. Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?
Player: Ignore me, then. It's your own funeral.
Jaheira: I'm not ignoring you - I just see no evidence of your rather outlandish claim. You've come from the shadows and wasted no time accusing one of our companions of treason. It's all a little... odd. A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer. But you're far from the most eccentric drinking companion I've had. I'd like to know more. Cheers. To your very good health.
Player: Jaheira, there's something you need to know: Marcus is a True Soul, and he's planning to kidnap Isobel.

Sazza: Mistress! It's me, yer loyal servant, Sazza. I'm back - an' I brought a friend.
Nightwarden Minthara: A duergar? Tell me, Sazza, did your misadventures take you to the Underdark?
Sazza: They woz in some rickety druid grove! Mostly full of tieflin's, but them intruders you're after were hidin' out there!
Nightwarden Minthara: I presume you dealt with my prey, and massacred the rest?
Sazza: Ah... well, the thing about that is... they sorta massacred us. This mug helped me escape though. I say we stick a few holes in them... show how grateful we are.

Narrator: *You feel a cold hand caress your mind as the drow appraises you.*
Nightwarden Minthara: Oh dear. Your prisoner is one of the Absolute's favourites, Sazza. A True Soul.
Sazza: Nah. Can't be... they woz in the grove, hangin' around with the tieflin's.
Nightwarden Minthara: Undercover, no doubt. Carrying out the Absolute's will. Oh, Sazza - you have made a grave error. And it will be your last. My spiders are hungry, little one... ...but before they feast, tell me where that grove is, and I may yet spare your life.
Sazza: It's past the bridge, to the east! Big ol' gate, covered in ivy! Don't hurt me, mistress. Please!
Nightwarden Minthara: I will not hurt you. My spiders will have that pleasure.
Sazza: No! I mucked up, I'm sorry! But I didn't know who they woz... they didn't tell me nothin'!
Player: You only have to look at me to know I'm your superior, wretch.
Sazza: Somebody help!

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up on  the player arriving in a secluded grove.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.
Gale: I love this time of night.
NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break. The cradle of eternity. The timelessness of lovers. That most beautiful of fantasies.
Player: It's breathtaking, Gale. Is this starry sky your doing?
Gale: Indeed. The curse is still present of course - just veiled and at arm's length for now. Not a trick I can repeat often, but tonight? Tonight is different. This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder... ...and with company to match.
NodeContext: Full of longing
Gale: I thought this place might bring me peace. I thought it might make the weight of what I must do feel a little lighter... but I am not so sure.
Player: Is this truly what you want, to die for the promise of Mystra's forgiveness?
Gale: Babe or crone, coward or hero, death is assured. Mystra's forgiveness is not. If you knew the end was near, would you not want to ensure it had meaning? I am terrified - I will not claim otherwise. My face could scarcely conceal it even if my words sought to deny it. There is no point in running from the inevitable. Better to meet it, on my own terms.
Player: You sound sure in your course of action then.
Gale: Resigned to it, rather. But that is not to say I am without fear. Far from it. Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'm not going anywhere, Gale. I'll be by your side, whatever dawn brings.
Gale: Yes... but there is so much to live for, and so few moments in which to house it all. Damn you. Damn you for giving me so much to care about. Our friends, our adventures... this would have been so much easier if it was just me. But it isn't. If there is a way - any way - to save all that's grown dear to me, I want to seize it. I just can't fathom what that might be, other than to fail Mystra and condemn the world. Stay with me, will you? I don't want to think of it any more, but I don't want to be alone either.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

Narrator: *The book is locked tight, with no visible keyhole - only an oval recess in the cover's mouth.* *You try to examine the book, but the longer you stare, the more those piercing, amethyst eyes draw you in.* *You can sense something dark about this tome - something profane.*
Lae'zel: A cursed book? How obvious. Whoever opens it deserves the fate that befalls them.
Shadowheart: Curious. Why don't you take a closer look... I'll observe from back here.

Karlach: Please don't open the creepy book.
Astarion: That looks terribly heavy. Why don't you let me carry it for you?
Wyll: We surely shouldn't just leave such a threat out, where anyone could stumble across it.
Player: Drop the tome, ready to destroy it.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Wait! Argh. Wait just a tick. Killing me is a waste of time - I'll find a way to return. Always have, always will. But it's... unpleasant. So how about we be civilised about this, hmm? I have something you want.
Player: What I want is Mayrina - alive and free.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: But she's worthless to you! Let me leave with the girl, and I'll give you power. You want to be stronger? Tougher? Smarter? Done! Anything is possible. (Ability Score +1) Just let me keep the girl and her babe.
Lae'zel: A simple trade? More deception. Take her head.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: It's your choice, sweetness.
Player: The human means nothing to me. Give me the power. Keep the girl. I'll take the power.

Sazza: Mistress! It's me, yer loyal servant, Sazza. I'm back - an' I brought a friend.
Nightwarden Minthara: How thoughtful. And where did you find this friend?
Sazza: They woz in some rickety druid grove! Mostly full of tieflin's, but them intruders you're after were hidin' out there!
Nightwarden Minthara: I presume you dealt with my prey, and massacred the rest?
Sazza: Ah... well, the thing about that is... they sorta massacred us. This mug helped me escape though. I say we stick a few holes in them... show how grateful we are.

Narrator: *You feel a cold hand caress your mind as the drow appraises you.*
Nightwarden Minthara: Oh dear. Your prisoner is one of the Absolute's favourites, Sazza. A True Soul.
Sazza: Nah. Can't be... they woz in the grove, hangin' around with the tieflin's.
Nightwarden Minthara: Undercover, no doubt. Carrying out the Absolute's will. Oh, Sazza - you have made a grave error. And it will be your last. My spiders are hungry, little one... ...but before they feast, tell me where that grove is, and I may yet spare your life.
Sazza: It's past the bridge, to the east! Big ol' gate, covered in ivy! Don't hurt me, mistress. Please!
Nightwarden Minthara: I will not hurt you. My spiders will have that pleasure.
Sazza: No! I mucked up, I'm sorry! But I didn't know who they woz... they didn't tell me nothin'!
Player: Keep quiet.
Sazza: You coulda told me who you woz! Somebody help!
Nightwarden Minthara: Through sheer luck, that pathetic worm has brought me the information I need. And it seems that the inhabitants of the grove trust you - we can use that against them. You have a part to play in this slaughter. Return to the grove. When my raiding party approaches, throw open the gate and signal me.
Narrator: *The fate of the grove's inhabitants hangs in the balance.* *Killing the drow here would spare them, but it might be better to face her warband at the grove itself, on familiar ground.* *On the other hand, participating in the slaughter as she asks may be the perfect way to earn her trust, and access to the cult's inner circle.*
Player: I want no part of this.
Nightwarden Minthara: I do not intend to lead a suicidal charge. The goblins are expendable; I am not. The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates and crush our enemies.
Player: All right. Expect me at the grove.

That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed. We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter. He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope. You are that hope.
Player: I'm trying my best to be...
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul. Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage. Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Jaheir takes the glass from the table.
Jaheira: This place is crawling with Harpers. If Marcus managed to get himself infected, we would've known the same minute. Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?
Player: I have proof, if you'll just come upstairs and look.
Jaheira: A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer. But you're far from the most eccentric drinking companion I've had. I'd like to know more. Cheers. To your very good health.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up on  the player arriving in a secluded grove.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.
Gale: I love this time of night.
NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break. The cradle of eternity. The timelessness of lovers. That most beautiful of fantasies.
Player: It's breathtaking, Gale. Is this starry sky your doing?
Gale: Indeed. The curse is still present of course - just veiled and at arm's length for now. Not a trick I can repeat often, but tonight? Tonight is different. This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder... ...and with company to match.
NodeContext: Full of longing
Gale: I thought this place might bring me peace. I thought it might make the weight of what I must do feel a little lighter... but I am not so sure.
Player: Are you not afraid?
Gale: Afraid? No, I am terrified. But fear or courage or reason cannot change the charge I've been given. There is no point in running from the inevitable. Better to meet it, on my own terms.
Player: Why are you so sure it's inevitable? We haven't even found this 'Heart of the Absolute' yet.
Gale: I can feel it - ever since we set foot in this strange, corrupted land. The closer we get, the heavier my own heart becomes. Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'm not going anywhere, Gale. I'll be by your side, whatever dawn brings.
Gale: Yes... but there is so much to live for, and so few moments in which to house it all. Damn you. Damn you for giving me so much to care about. Our friends, our adventures... this would have been so much easier if it was just me. But it isn't. If there is a way - any way - to save all that's grown dear to me, I want to seize it. I just can't fathom what that might be, other than to fail Mystra and condemn the world. Stay with me, will you? I don't want to think of it any more, but I don't want to be alone either.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

Nightwarden Minthara: A drow? Tell me, Sazza, did your misadventures take you to the Underdark?
Sazza: They woz in some rickety druid grove! Mostly full of tieflin's, but them intruders you're after were hidin' out there!
Nightwarden Minthara: I presume you dealt with my prey, and massacred the rest?
Sazza: Ah... well, the thing about that is... they sorta massacred us. I got myself nabbed though; ended up all snug in a cage instead of smashed. I'm wily like that. And then the Absolute answered my prayers - sent a True Soul to save me!
Nightwarden Minthara: You are a True Soul. And it seems that the inhabitants of the grove trust you - we can use that against them. You have a part to play in this slaughter. Return to the grove. When my raiding party approaches, throw open the gate and signal me.
Narrator: *The fate of the grove's inhabitants hangs in the balance.* *Killing the drow here would spare them, but it might be better to face her warband at the grove itself, on familiar ground.* *On the other hand, participating in the slaughter as she asks may be the perfect way to earn her trust, and access to the cult's inner circle.*
Player: I want no part of this.
Nightwarden Minthara: I do not intend to lead a suicidal charge. The goblins are expendable; I am not. The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates and crush our enemies.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.
Gale: I love this time of night.
NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break. The cradle of eternity. The timelessness of lovers. That most beautiful of fantasies.
Player: It's breathtaking, Gale. Is this starry sky your doing?
Gale: Indeed. The curse is still present of course - just veiled and at arm's length for now. Not a trick I can repeat often, but tonight? Tonight is different. This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder... ...and with company to match.
NodeContext: Full of longing
Gale: I thought this place might bring me peace. I thought it might make the weight of what I must do feel a little lighter... but I am not so sure.
Player: Are you not afraid?
Gale: Afraid? No, I am terrified. But fear or courage or reason cannot change the charge I've been given. There is no point in running from the inevitable. Better to meet it, on my own terms.
Player: You're right. At least this way, you might take the Absolute down with you.
Gale: I can only hope that there are few innocents within the Absolute's reach, when the time comes... and that you will seek safety, far away from me. Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'm not going anywhere, Gale. I'll be by your side, whatever dawn brings.
Gale: Yes... but there is so much to live for, and so few moments in which to house it all. Damn you. Damn you for giving me so much to care about. Our friends, our adventures... this would have been so much easier if it was just me. But it isn't. If there is a way - any way - to save all that's grown dear to me, I want to seize it. I just can't fathom what that might be, other than to fail Mystra and condemn the world. Stay with me, will you? I don't want to think of it any more, but I don't want to be alone either.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Wait! Argh. Wait just a tick. Killing me is a waste of time - I'll find a way to return. Always have, always will. But it's... unpleasant. So how about we be civilised about this, hmm? I have something you want.
Player: Hah! This should be good.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: If you're gloating now, just wait 'til you hear my offer, petal. Let me leave with the girl, and I'll give you power. You want to be stronger? Tougher? Smarter? Done! Anything is possible. (Ability Score +1) Just let me keep the girl and her babe.
Gale: Not only would this be a vile deal, it would be folly to trust a hag's gifts.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: It's your choice, sweetness.
Player: Keep the girl. I'll take the power.

Player: Give Gale a magic artefact.
Gale: Perhaps I'm not conveying the urgency of the situation. It's incredibly, world-shatteringly important you give me a suitable artefact. Please.
Player: Give Gale a suitable artefact.
Gale: My condition requires a delicate touch. Just one item will suffice to keep it in check.
Player: Understood. I'll give you what you need.
Gale: My condition requires a delicate touch. Just one item will suffice to keep it in check.
Player: Understood. I'll give you what you need.

Player: Understood. I'll give you what you need.
Gale: Perhaps I'm not conveying the urgency of the situation. It's incredibly, world-shatteringly important you give me a suitable artefact. Please.
Player: I'm not giving you anything. Not now, not ever.

Gale: A word, if you please. Remember how I told you I was in dire need of magical artefacts to absorb? Clearly the matter has hardly been a priority of yours, but even so, you can consider it closed. I no longer require assistance - neither yours, nor that of artefacts.
Player: I don't follow. This seems awfully sudden.
Gale: Not at all. I've had a solution in mind for a while now, it just took me some time to... set it in motion. That's it - I won't take more of your time this lovely evening. Rest well.
Player: Something's off. Try to connect with Gale without him noticing.
Narrator: *You flutter through his mind like a bat through the night and you see...* *... fire. You hear laughter. You smell brimstone.* *Mocking words drift back to you. 'This is the House of Hope.'*
Gale: Stop that! How dare you... Forget whatever it was you saw. It's all beyond you now anyway.

Narrator: *The book is locked tight, with no visible keyhole - only an oval recess in the cover's mouth.* *You try to examine the book, but the longer you stare, the more those piercing, amethyst eyes draw you in.* *Beneath the allure, you feel the faintest echo of torment. There is great power in this book, but also great suffering.*
Lae'zel: A cursed book? How obvious. Whoever opens it deserves the fate that befalls them.
Shadowheart: Curious. Why don't you take a closer look... I'll observe from back here.

Karlach: Please don't open the creepy book.
Astarion: That looks terribly heavy. Why don't you let me carry it for you?
Wyll: We surely shouldn't just leave such a threat out, where anyone could stumble across it.
Player: Open the book.

Sazza: Mistress! It's me, yer loyal servant, Sazza. I'm back - an' I brought a friend.
Nightwarden Minthara: How thoughtful. And where did you find this friend?
Sazza: They woz in some rickety druid grove! Mostly full of tieflin's, but them intruders you're after were hidin' out there!
Nightwarden Minthara: I presume you dealt with my prey, and massacred the rest?
Sazza: Ah... well, the thing about that is... they sorta massacred us. This mug helped me escape though. I say we stick a few holes in them... show how grateful we are.

Narrator: *You feel a cold hand caress your mind as the drow appraises you.*
Nightwarden Minthara: Oh dear. Your prisoner is one of the Absolute's favourites, Sazza. A True Soul.
Sazza: Nah. Can't be... they woz in the grove, hangin' around with the tieflin's.
Nightwarden Minthara: Undercover, no doubt. Carrying out the Absolute's will. Oh, Sazza - you have made a grave error. And it will be your last. My spiders are hungry, little one... ...but before they feast, tell me where that grove is, and I may yet spare your life.
Sazza: It's past the bridge, to the east! Big ol' gate, covered in ivy! Don't hurt me, mistress. Please!
Nightwarden Minthara: I will not hurt you. My spiders will have that pleasure.
Sazza: No! I mucked up, I'm sorry! But I didn't know who they woz... they didn't tell me nothin'!
Player: I explained everything to her. She's just too stupid to understand.
Nightwarden Minthara: A liar as well as a fool? I hope you're at least digestible.
Sazza: It ain't true! Them's the bloody liars! Somebody help!
Nightwarden Minthara: Through sheer luck, that pathetic worm has brought me the information I need. And it seems that the inhabitants of the grove trust you - we can use that against them. You have a part to play in this slaughter. Return to the grove. When my raiding party approaches, throw open the gate and signal me.
Narrator: *The fate of the grove's inhabitants hangs in the balance.* *Killing the drow here would spare them, but it might be better to face her warband at the grove itself, on familiar ground.* *On the other hand, participating in the slaughter as she asks may be the perfect way to earn her trust, and access to the cult's inner circle.*
Player: I want no part of this.
Nightwarden Minthara: I do not intend to lead a suicidal charge. The goblins are expendable; I am not. The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates and crush our enemies.
Player: All right. Expect me at the grove.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Wait! Argh. Wait just a tick. Killing me is a waste of time - I'll find a way to return. Always have, always will. But it's... unpleasant. So how about we be civilised about this, hmm? I have something you want.
Player: Hah! This should be good.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: If you're gloating now, just wait 'til you hear my offer, petal. Let me leave with the girl, and I'll give you power. You want to be stronger? Tougher? Smarter? Done! Anything is possible. (Ability Score +1) Just let me keep the girl and her babe.
Lae'zel: A simple trade? More deception. Take her head.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: It's your choice, sweetness.
Player: The human means nothing to me. Give me the power. Keep the girl. I'll take the power.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help. The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation. We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold. I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed. We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter. He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope. You are that hope.
Player: It's rare people look at me and see 'hope'.
Jaheira: The light is rather dim, out here in the shadowlands. The point remains: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul. Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage. Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Jaheir takes the glass from the table.
Jaheira: This place is crawling with Harpers. If Marcus managed to get himself infected, we would've known the same minute. Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?
Player: Ignore me, then. It's your own funeral.
Jaheira: I'm not ignoring you - I just see no evidence of your rather outlandish claim. You've come from the shadows and wasted no time accusing one of our companions of treason. It's all a little... odd. A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer.
Player: Jaheira, there's something you need to know: Marcus is a True Soul, and he's planning to kidnap Isobel.
Jaheira: This place is crawling with Harpers. If Marcus managed to get himself infected, we would've known the same minute. Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?
Player: I have proof, if you'll just come upstairs and look.
Jaheira: A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer.
Player: And I'll drink to the darkness that will soon fall when I drag Isobel all the way to Moonrise Towers.

Karlach: Please! She's dreaming if she thinks we'd leave Mayrina here.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: It's your choice, sweetness.
Player: Such power will let me better serve the Spider Queen. Give it to me. Keep the girl. I'll take the power.

Gale: I can only hope that there are few innocents within the Absolute's reach, when the time comes... and that you will seek safety, far away from me. Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'm not going anywhere, Gale. I'll be by your side, whatever dawn brings.
Gale: Yes... but there is so much to live for, and so few moments in which to house it all. Damn you. Damn you for giving me so much to care about. Our friends, our adventures... this would have been so much easier if it was just me. But it isn't. If there is a way - any way - to save all that's grown dear to me, I want to seize it. I just can't fathom what that might be, other than to fail Mystra and condemn the world. Stay with me, will you? I don't want to think of it any more, but I don't want to be alone either.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

Sazza: Mistress! It's me, yer loyal servant, Sazza. I'm back - an' I brought a friend.
Nightwarden Minthara: A duergar? Tell me, Sazza, did your misadventures take you to the Underdark?
Sazza: They woz in some rickety druid grove! Mostly full of tieflin's, but them intruders you're after were hidin' out there!
Nightwarden Minthara: I presume you dealt with my prey, and massacred the rest?
Sazza: Ah... well, the thing about that is... they sorta massacred us. This mug helped me escape though. I say we stick a few holes in them... show how grateful we are.

Narrator: *You feel a cold hand caress your mind as the drow appraises you.*
Nightwarden Minthara: Oh dear. Your prisoner is one of the Absolute's favourites, Sazza. A True Soul.
Sazza: Nah. Can't be... they woz in the grove, hangin' around with the tieflin's.
Nightwarden Minthara: Undercover, no doubt. Carrying out the Absolute's will. Oh, Sazza - you have made a grave error. And it will be your last. My spiders are hungry, little one... ...but before they feast, tell me where that grove is, and I may yet spare your life.
Sazza: It's past the bridge, to the east! Big ol' gate, covered in ivy! Don't hurt me, mistress. Please!
Nightwarden Minthara: I will not hurt you. My spiders will have that pleasure.
Sazza: No! I mucked up, I'm sorry! But I didn't know who they woz... they didn't tell me nothin'!
Player: Keep quiet.
Sazza: You coulda told me who you woz! Somebody help!
Nightwarden Minthara: Through sheer luck, that pathetic worm has brought me the information I need. And it seems that the inhabitants of the grove trust you - we can use that against them. You have a part to play in this slaughter. Return to the grove. When my raiding party approaches, throw open the gate and signal me.
Narrator: *The fate of the grove's inhabitants hangs in the balance.* *Killing the drow here would spare them, but it might be better to face her warband at the grove itself, on familiar ground.* *On the other hand, participating in the slaughter as she asks may be the perfect way to earn her trust, and access to the cult's inner circle.*
Player: I'll get it done.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help. The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation. We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold. I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed. We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter. He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope. You are that hope.
Player: I'm trying my best to be...
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul. Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage. Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Jaheir takes the glass from the table.
Jaheira: This place is crawling with Harpers. If Marcus managed to get himself infected, we would've known the same minute. Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?
Player: Absolutely not. Marcus is a danger to you all.
Jaheira: A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer. But you're far from the most eccentric drinking companion I've had. I'd like to know more. Cheers. To your very good health.
Player: Jaheira, there's something you need to know: Marcus is a True Soul, and he's planning to kidnap Isobel.
Jaheira: This place is crawling with Harpers. If Marcus managed to get himself infected, we would've known the same minute. Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?
Player: Absolutely not. Marcus is a danger to you all.

Player: Absolutely not. Marcus is a danger to you all.
Jaheira: A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer. But you're far from the most eccentric drinking companion I've had. I'd like to know more. Cheers. To your very good health.
Player: And I'll drink to the darkness that will soon fall when I drag Isobel all the way to Moonrise Towers.

Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Nere mentioned that you were seeking access to the Temple. Looks like you found it.
Balthazar: Perhaps you'd be more useful dead than alive if you don't even know what I'm seeking here. But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create. General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall. You and all the rest have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make. You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: As you mention serving Ketheric, he sent you to find a relic, no?
Balthazar: General Thorm to you. But yes, recovering the relic is the crux of it. He commands, and I, his humble servant, fulfil that command. While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: What are the properties of this relic, magical or otherwise? So I can be of better assistance, of course. I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
Balthazar: Fine, if it'll spare me your bleating. The relic lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work... Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell... ...Hmm. Misplaced, it seems. You will be capable enough without it.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Vlaakith: Inquisitor W'wargaz was potent. We are impressed.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The planecaster vibrates, shaking the ground around it.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Vlaakith gha'g shkath zai!
NodeContext: pronounced VLAH-kith gawg shkaath ZAI (meaning 'For the honour of Vlaakith!')
Lae'zel: My Queen - shkath zai!
NodeContext: shkaath ZAI - for the honour!
Vlaakith: You are permitted to look upon me. You are invited to kneel.
Lae'zel: The Deathless Queen has spoken. You will obey.
Player: Stay standing, exactly as you are.
Vlaakith: Did your cr√®che teach you nothing?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith, unfazed in the least, motions everyone present to rise.l Everyone rises.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face Lae'zel at their eye level.
Vlaakith: Your choice of allies is most vexing. They do not become you. Lae'zel.
Lae'zel: Ch'mar, zal'a Vlaakith. You know me.
Vlaakith: Urlon of K'liir speaks most highly. As did Al'chaia before him. You seek purity. I may yet grant it.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith turns to player and looms over them instead.
Vlaakith: Istik. You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: I didn't take the weapon from you, but I am returning it.
Vlaakith: An unexpected servant. Your will is strong. Descendant of noble dragons - you honour us with your allyship. Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning. That 'weapon' you carry - the Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Lae'zel: I will cleanse it for you, my Queen. Tell me how.
Vlaakith: There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight. They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire. As long as they live, the Prism is compromised. Kill them. Do this, and I will cleanse you and your allies. Do this - - and ascend.
Lae'zel: Ascension? My queen. An honour gained, a burden borne. Choose. But know this: the cost of refusal is great.
Vlaakith: Not merely great, Lae'zel. Eternal.
Player: I will do as you wish.

Counsellor Florrick: You're too late. It's over.
Wyll: By Avernus - Florrick.
Counsellor Florrick: Wyll? Is that you? What curse has befallen you? No matter. The city, the future. It's done.
Player: I don't understand. What do you mean?
Counsellor Florrick: I came seeking allies to our cause. Watchers spotted me, dragged me to Ulder Ravengard's husk. Empty as a stare. Your father's a tadpole's puppet, Wyll. Nothing more. Empty as a stare. A tadpole's puppet, nothing more. He spoke in accusations. Apostasy, conspiracy, sedition. I'll be executed in five dawns. You might have unlocked my cell, but there's no escape from this place.
Wyll: The Hells with that. Nothing is over. Not while I still draw breath.
Player: Ravengard's dead. The city needs you - I'm getting you out.
Counsellor Florrick: He's - dead? So perishes the city. I can - I can scarcely bear it. Forget it. Baldur's Gate's good as cinder. An illithid hive beyond saving.
Narrator: *You recall the tales of Gorion's Ward, the great hero of Baldur's Gate. Without them, the city would have succumbed to war, famine, and worse.*
Player: Coward. Balduran didn't build the Gate for you to weep as it burns. Gorion's Ward overcame great odds to protect the city. You can do the same.
Counsellor Florrick: 'When the people need a miracle, you cannot wait for the gods to answer.' Ulder's words. I'd almost forgotten. No more sulking. I know what to do. Lead me from my cell, escort me out of Wyrm's Rock. I'll seek out my connections. When the city's streets shatter, you'll want their blades.
Player: I won't help you.

Arabella: That's who I'm looking for. Mum and pops, I mean. When Zevlor - when he - Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran. I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't. Still can't find 'em - but I bet you can. You'll help me, I just know it!
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*

Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.

Arabella: I'll prove it. Let me help in the camp, til you bring mom and pops back to me. Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!

Liam: T-to the east. P-past the ruins and the bridge. The gate's covered with ivy. But please... please don't tell the goblins!

Liam: S-somewhere underneath the temple. There's a hidden p-passage. B-Brian had instructions, but... the g-goblins got him. They - they said they'd e-eat him... P-please, these shackles... I... I don't want to die!

Liam: Halsin? I... I don't know. He changed into a bear, but... I lost sight of him. I don't know if he's s-still alive. That's all I know! Please... g-get me out of here!

Player: You think a few shadows could beat me?
Alfira: ...Wait. No one's told you? We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Someone told them to rot in the Nine Hells, that we weren't going anywhere. Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Which one was Asharak again?
Alfira: Which...? Back in the grove, he ran drills with the kids. Wooden swords and the like. That seems like a lifetime ago now. Rolan, of all people, saved us. He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: What did the cultists do to the others?

Player: Actually, I may just want to spend the night with you instead of Wyll.

Allow me to make the following proposition: There's a book that circulates in Amn, detailing the first thousand nights of a newlywed king and queen. They turned everything they did into an art. The art of conversation. The art of taste, time honoured and newly acquired. The art of the body. The exploration and acceptance of the self and the other. The art of the night itself. I say we take a page from their book.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me. An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: I prefer a weapon to a stench, thanks.
Gandrel: Sharp steel is not proof against all the monsters of this world, my friend. A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house. That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: Why would you assume that?
Gandrel: Because this is her domain. If you are here, it is because it suits her. Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite. Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: I think you're mistaken - this place looks innocent enough.
Gandrel: That would be nice. I'd welcome a proper cup of tea. But I'm not wrong. Take her lightly, and she'll serve up your eyes for appetisers. I'll eat them, too. I need her knowledge - the thing I hunt has gone to ground. But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: Who is it you're hunting?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it. Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: Come now - I've almost certainly killed worse.
Gandrel: I would not be so sure. But I won't keep the truth from you. I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive. Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: We've met - he's not the type to come quietly.
Gandrel: You do know him? I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is? But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?

Gale: Thank you.
NodeContext: You look at the player with a big smile and the words are warm and heartfelt.
Player: Spontaneous thank-yous make me suspicious.
Gale: Come now! This is a night for celebration, not suspicion. I thank you for seeking me out. Amidst all this merriment I wasn't sure we'd have a chance to speak this evening. More's the pity you've already found someone else to make merry with, just the two of you. Lae'zel. Blade like a razor, wit like a razor, tongue like a razor. I do hope you know what you're doing. Far be it from me of course, to question your tastes.
Player: Actually, I may just want to spend the night with you instead of Wyll.
Gale: Indeed? We shared a romantic moment of the mind while cloaked in the Weave, didn't we? And I seem to recall a fond allusion to that moment afterwards. Allow me to make the following proposition: There's a book that circulates in Amn, detailing the first thousand nights of a newlywed king and queen. They turned everything they did into an art. The art of conversation. The art of taste, time honoured and newly acquired. The art of the body. The exploration and acceptance of the self and the other. The art of the night itself. I say we take a page from their book.
Player: Leave it to you to woo someone with a book.
Gale: Forget the book then. Let's be blank slates on blank sheets, delightfully new. What do you say?
Player: I'm not sure you're the one I want.
Gale: That's because you've yet to find out what you're missing. Doubt is a spoilsport. Cast it aside.
Player: No. Another time maybe.
Gale: Too bad. One should never be afraid to live life to the fullest. But before you go... I know there are many things about me that remain shrouded in mystery. You've been very patient with me, and I appreciate that. You've given me powerful magic to consume when I needed it most. You've brought me back from the grey shores of death. You know of my condition, and you know about my unfortunate efforts to win Mystra's favour, but those are but the broad strokes. The time has come to paint you the true picture.

Alfira: First cultists nearly murder us, and now we have a traitor on the inside? Can't we trust anyone?
NodeContext: frustrated and tired of being scared
Player: Cultists? What happened?
Alfira: Stars, you hadn't heard?
 We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Ikaron was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.
 Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: How did you survive?
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us. He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: You're lucky to be alive.
Alfira: I don't feel lucky. I feel... I feel like I'm at the end of my rope. How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: 'When the night is dark, stars shine brightest.' So keep on shining. It's going to be all right.
Alfira: 'Heart's Requiem', right? The hero survives a war and rebuilds her life - stronger than ever. A tale worth remembering - especially now. You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there. If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Nere mentioned that you were seeking access to the Temple. Looks like you found it.
Balthazar: Perhaps you'd be more useful dead than alive if you don't even know what I'm seeking here. But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create. General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall. You and all the rest have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make. You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: As you mention serving Ketheric, he sent you to find a relic, no?
Balthazar: General Thorm to you. But yes, recovering the relic is the crux of it. He commands, and I, his humble servant, fulfil that command. While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: So you need my help - what would I have to do? What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: You have resources to spare - give me something to aid my search.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell... ...and he will come. My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do. I'll see what I can do.

Player: Gorion's Ward overcame great odds to protect the city. You can do the same.
Counsellor Florrick: 'When the people need a miracle, you cannot wait for the gods to answer.' Ulder's words. I'd almost forgotten. No more sulking. I know what to do. Unlock my cell, escort me out of Wyrm's Rock. I'll seek out my connections. When the city's streets shatter, you'll want their blades.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale takes book out (of his own inventory),
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: That devil Raphael was telling the truth. There's no doubt - the Crown of Karsus is what's controlling the elder brain. And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: A design you could follow?
Gale: Not from scratch - unless you happen to have several pounds of the purest Netherese metals in that pack of yours? Don't worry - I'm not asking you to surrender anything else on my account. What's called for here is something altogether different. The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall. If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: That Crown's caused chaos. We should be seeking a way to destroy it, not make it more powerful.
Gale: Do not mistake the crown itself for the actions of its wearer, or rather, those controlling its wearer at present. If we could restore its former glory, it would no longer be a mere leash and collar, used to subjugate friend or foe. It would be something greater. Something divine. Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations. I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: You dismiss the entire pantheon so easily. Not all gods are selfish.
Gale: Some gods may delude themselves into believing they care about their worshippers, but when it comes down to it - we're all expendable. Children to be appeased, not respected. I worshipped Mystra loyally for years, and in that time she granted me the barest sliver of the power I was ready to wield. Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us. Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: Or to destroy the next wizard who attempts it. The attempt would kill you as it killed Karsus.
Gale: Do you think I had not considered that? I have no intention of repeating his folly. Powerful as he was, Karsus lacked some advantages I can lay claim to. I know Mystra - intimately. And I carry a fragment of the Weave itself within my body. Karsus achieved many things, but he never managed that. A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: What you're suggesting is blasphemy. You'd be wise to banish these notions from your head.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully. I've spent so long feeling... inferior, shut out from my destiny over such a simple act of youthful enthusiasm. Perhaps I got carried away with the thought this Crown could give me back what Mystra took. Cure me, even.

Ulma: Rech t√© i hathran roost.
NodeContext: REK tay ee HATH-ran ROOST
Ulma: Frey vald isk durovna. Frey vald isk ablast.
Narrator: *You recognise the funeral rites of the Gur people - the same monster hunters you met in the hag's swamp. Their leader is burning the possessions of those who have fallen.*
Ulma: Im orak ne tay. Krasin ne trah!
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Ulma pauses for a moment, staring at the fire in contemplation before she turns and walks over to the player.
Ulma: So, the impossible spawn walks among us in the blazing sun. We have been looking for you.
Astarion: Really? You should have tried looking harder.
Gandrel: I looked for you high and low, across mountain and swamp. You were an elusive quarry indeed.
Ulma: The last time you came to our camp, you stole our children. Our future.
Gandrel: When I was hunting you, I was to bring you back here. To interrogate you, discover how to save our children, and then destroy you.
Ulma: But things have changed. You have changed. Is it true you left your master? That you broke the spell that binds you to him?
Astarion: Yes, it's true.
Ulma: Then maybe you have a chance to redeem yourself. We have tried to save our children once already, attacking the vampire's palace at first light. Even then, it was too well defended. But you - you are someone he wants. Someone he thinks he can control, but with powers beyond his imagining. He will throw his doors open to you, lower his defences, and you will save the children you damned.
Astarion: You think you can guilt me into doing what you're too weak to?
Ulma: We offer you a chance, perhaps your final chance, to heal just some of the pain you have caused. So, tell us - who are you? Someone worthy of redemption or the monster the world believes you to be?
Astarion: Forget it, I'm not sacrificing myself for your cause.

Cerys: Thought you'd be ten yards tall, the way my people speak of you. Cerys. Scout. Seems we missed one another at the grove, but the others told me how you helped us. A pity. You pulled them from one death-trap only for me to land them in this one.
Player: I don't see Zevlor. Don't tell me he's missing aswell?
Cerys: Aye, and more than half the others with him. We were ambushed out in the cursed lands - cultists of this Absolute. Likely we should have surrendered, but... They were toying with us. Making examples. And we'd had enough of taking it. Those of us who cut free just kept running 'til we found this place. The others... maybe the cult got them. Maybe the curse.
Player: Have you no shame? You were tasked with protecting these people, yet you ran.

Vlaakith: So - it is found.
NodeContext: Vlaakith should sligjhtly overpronounce every word, think Davros from Doctor Who, each syllable drips with a kind of mad, ancient evil
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The planecaster vibrates, shaking the ground around it.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Vlaakith gha'g shkath zai!
NodeContext: pronounced VLAH-kith gawg shkaath ZAI (meaning 'For the honour of Vlaakith!')
Lae'zel: My queen.
Narrator: *Your vision throbs with ink-black darkness as your patron borrows your gaze - beholding the vision in front of you.* *Not exactly a god - but not far off. Your patron recoils, but not before leaving a word of advice - caution.*
Vlaakith: You are permitted to look upon me. You are invited to kneel.
Player: Kneel before Vlaakith, your queen.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player kneels, head bowed, solemn, appropriate. Vlaakith offers something resembling a smile, and gestures for the player to rise. The player rises.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face the player at their eye level.
Vlaakith: You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: Friend - I came to bring it back to you.
Shadowheart: Fool - that artefact is the only thing keeping us safe. She cannot have it.
Vlaakith: An unexpected servant. Your will is strong. Descendant of noble dragons - you honour us with your allyship. Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning. The Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I shall cleanse it for you, my queen. Tell me how.
InternalNodeContext: He's not altogether sure why this task is falling to the player and not to him, but also doesn't want to challenge his queen's motivations.
Vlaakith: SILENCE, W'wargaz. There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight. They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire. As long as they live, the Prism is compromised. Find the one inside and destroy them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed.
Player: So the dream visitor is inside the artefact... I can't kill them. They protect me from the Absolute.
Vlaakith: You are being LIED TO. I WILL BE OBEYED!
NodeContext: she loses herself a bit in rage here,
Player: Fine. I will go in and kill them.

Arabella: Hey - I know you! You're -

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The creatures groan menacingly and prepare to lunge
Arabella: Twist'em up!
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella casts her spell. Before the creatures can attack, vines rise from the ground and wrap around them, entangling them to her right

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella turns away from the trapped creature, exhausted.
Arabella: Sorry. Knocks the wind right out of me.
Player: Normally tales of stolen artefacts are tragedies - I'm glad you've bucked that trend.
Arabella: Tragedies? Them's the sad ones, right? I hope not. 'Specially since mum and pops - After Zevlor - When he - Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran. I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't.
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*
Player: Your parents are test-fodder stuffed full of needles, little orphan.
Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.
Player: And are you tough enough?
Arabella: I'll prove it. Let me help in the camp, til you bring mom and pops back to me. Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!
Player: Forget it. No kids in my camp.

Player: Reach into the light and take the mace.
Shadowheart: Not one to heed warning then? This could end very badly.

Gale: Are you quite sure that's wise?
Shadowheart: We should leave that thing and just get out of here while we can.

Narrator: *The glow around the mace sparkles with beautiful disaster.* *You recall all the measures meant to keep you from reaching this place.* *Taking this mace would surely lead to something quite disastrous.* *The brutal aches in your body yearn to take it, though you sense it will spell misfortune.*
Player: Claim the mace and delight in its danger.

Counsellor Florrick: You might as well lock the cell. You're too late. It's over.
Jaheira: Florrick? What have they done to you?
Counsellor Florrick: I don't speak of myself, High Harper. I speak of the city itself - we came too late. It's over.
Player: Counsellor. What happened to you?

Nothing more. Empty as a stare. A tadpole's puppet, nothing more. He spoke in accusations. Apostasy, conspiracy, sedition. I will soon be hanged on the city gallows to a chorus of cheers. You might have unlocked my cell, but there's no escape from this place.

Counsellor Florrick: Wyll? Is that you? What curse has befallen you? No matter. The city, the future. It's done.
Player: Counsellor. What happened to you?
Counsellor Florrick: The Steel Watch happened. I came seeking allies to our cause. Watchers spotted me, dragged me to Ulder Ravengard's husk. Empty as a stare. Your father's a tadpole's puppet, Wyll. Nothing more. Empty as a stare. A tadpole's puppet, nothing more. He spoke in accusations. Apostasy, conspiracy, sedition. I'll be executed in five dawns. You might have unlocked my cell, but there's no escape from this place.
Wyll: The Hells with that. Nothing is over. Not while I still draw breath.
Player: Ravengard's dead. The city needs you - I'm getting you out.
Counsellor Florrick: He's - dead? So perishes the city. I can - I can scarcely bear it. Forget it. Baldur's Gate's good as cinder. An illithid hive beyond saving.
Narrator: *You recall the tales of Gorion's Ward, the great hero of Baldur's Gate. Without them, the city would have succumbed to war, famine, and worse.*
Player: Gorion's Ward overcame great odds to protect the city. You can do the same.
Counsellor Florrick: 'When the people need a miracle, you cannot wait for the gods to answer.' Ulder's words. I'd almost forgotten. No more sulking. I know what to do. Unlock my cell, escort me out of Wyrm's Rock. I'll seek out my connections. When the city's streets shatter, you'll want their blades.
