Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create. General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall. You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: As you mention serving Ketheric, he sent you to find a relic, no?
Balthazar: General Thorm to you. But yes, recovering the relic is the crux of it. He commands, and I, his humble servant, fulfil that command. While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him might just be the best way to gain access to Moonrise Towers.* *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
Balthazar: Fine, if it'll spare me your bleating. The relic lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.

Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell... ...and he will come. My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me. An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: Whatever you're hunting, your stench alone will kill it.
Gandrel: Hah! A quick wit is rare indeed. Good manners, however, all beings can aspire to. I suggest you find yours before dealing with the lady of this house. A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house. That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: 'The lady of this house'?
Gandrel: A more innocent name than some I could call her. But it is what she is that ought to concern you. Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite. Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: So I learned.
Gandrel: Ah - so you did. I thought you were just squinting from the stink. But, one fool to another, I can't say I judge you. The thing I hunt has slipped away from me. If she can tell me how to flush him out, I'll pay whatever price she asks. But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: Who is it you're hunting?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it. Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: There's enough deception in this place - don't add to it.
Gandrel: It is not everyone who can see past her parlour tricks. As you wish - the truth is not mine to keep. I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive. Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: We've met - he's not the type to come quietly.
Gandrel: You do know him? I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is? But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?

Gale: Thank you.
NodeContext: You look at the player with a big smile and the words are warm and heartfelt.
Player: Spontaneous thank-yous make me suspicious.
Gale: Come now! This is a night for celebration, not suspicion. I thank you for seeking me out. Amidst all this merriment I wasn't sure we'd have a chance to speak this evening. More's the pity you've already found someone else to make merry with, just the two of you. Lae'zel. Blade like a razor, wit like a razor, tongue like a razor. I do hope you know what you're doing. Far be it from me of course, to question your tastes.
Player: Actually, I may just want to spend the night with you instead of Lae'zel.
Gale: Indeed? We had a moment, you and I, a moment in which we expressed the possibility of becoming more than friends. Tonight seems perfectly suited for such endeavours. Allow me to make the following proposition: There's a book that circulates in Amn, detailing the first thousand nights of a newlywed king and queen. They turned everything they did into an art. The art of conversation. The art of taste, time honoured and newly acquired. The art of the body. The exploration and acceptance of the self and the other. The art of the night itself. I say we take a page from their book.
Player: Let me stop you right there. That's not something I'm interested in.
Gale: Too bad. One should never be afraid to live life to the fullest. But before you go... I know there are many things about me that remain shrouded in mystery. You've been very patient with me, and I appreciate that. I was given powerful magic to consume when I needed it most. You've brought me back from the grey shores of death. You know of my condition, and you know about my unfortunate efforts to win Mystra's favour, but those are but the broad strokes. The time has come to paint you the true picture.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me. An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: Who are you?
Gandrel: Today? The same as you - a humble supplicant, come to bargain with the lady of this house. A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house. That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: 'The lady of this house'?
Gandrel: A more innocent name than some I could call her. But it is what she is that ought to concern you. Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite. Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: And are you fool enough?
Gandrel: Of course. I'm a hunter who lost his prey, and here I am seeking help from something worse. But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: Who is it you're hunting?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it. Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: I like danger. The truth - now.
Gandrel: Perhaps I was... hasty with my words. I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive. Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: You can give up your hunt. Astarion's under my protection.
Gandrel: ...I see. Your loyalty is admirable but misplaced. His kind have charm beyond our mortal means to resist. I can show you who he truly is - if you will just tell me where to find him. But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?

Gale: If my suspicions are correct, the crown currently perched atop the elder brain may be one of Karsus' design. And now we hold the very tome that could confirm it.
Player: Don't stand on ceremony - see what it says.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale takes book out (of his own inventory),
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: That devil Raphael was telling the truth. There's no doubt - the Crown of Karsus is what's controlling the elder brain. And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: A design you could follow?
Gale: Not from scratch - unless you happen to have several pounds of the purest Netherese metals in that pack of yours? Don't worry - I'm not asking you to surrender anything else on my account. What's called for here is something altogether different. The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall. If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: To what end?
Gale: To every end you can imagine, and a thousand more beyond. Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations. I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: And you think Mystra will let you do this?
Gale: I don't know. Ao does not look kindly on gods meddling in mortal affairs - she may have no choice but to stand by and let events unfold. Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us. Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: This is no ordinary artefact, Gale. Do this and you'd challenge the gods themselves.
Gale: Perhaps they deserve to be challenged. Perhaps you and I deserve better than to live and die as their pawns. Ambition is not a sin. To question the powers that rule us is not treason. We must at least try - why wallow in the dirt when we can reach for the stars? A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: What you're suggesting is blasphemy. You'd be wise to banish these notions from your head.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully. I've spent so long feeling... inferior, shut out from my destiny over such a simple act of youthful enthusiasm. Perhaps I got carried away with the thought this Crown could give me back what Mystra took. Cure me, even.

Counsellor Florrick: You might as well lock the cell. You're too late. It's over.
Jaheira: Florrick? What have they done to you?
Counsellor Florrick: I don't speak of myself, High Harper. I speak of the city itself - we came too late. It's over.
Player: So you're giving up, just like that?
Counsellor Florrick: I didn't give up. I lost. I came seeking allies to our cause. Watchers spotted me, dragged me to Ulder Ravengard's husk. Empty as a stare. Your father's a tadpole's puppet, Wyll. Nothing more. Empty as a stare. A tadpole's puppet, nothing more. He spoke in accusations. Apostasy, conspiracy, sedition. I will soon be hanged on the city gallows to a chorus of cheers. You might have unlocked my cell, but there's no escape from this place.
Jaheira: The Fist can go hang themselves - we're getting you out.
Player: I'm breaking you out. Baldur's Gate needs you. Ravengard needs you. Gorion's Ward overcame great odds to protect the city. You can do the same.
Counsellor Florrick: 'When the people need a miracle, you cannot wait for the gods to answer.' Ulder's words. I'd almost forgotten. No more sulking. I know what to do. Lead me from my cell, escort me out of Wyrm's Rock. I'll seek out my connections. When the city's streets shatter, you'll want their blades.
Player: I won't help you.

He Who Was: The air stirs in trepidation - you have the ledger.
Player: Here - take it.
He Who Was: We have it - her lies, her guilt. Madeline reported her friends to a Dark Justiciar and fled when they were butchered. Well, she flees no more. I will be the conduit for Madeline's spirit. I will force her to face trial. And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: Let's see what she has to say first.
He Who Was: Careful - for a serpent in life is a serpent in death. Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Karlach: Pot, meet kettle.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining. The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: Don't blame others for what you did.
Madeline: You didn't see it. Didn't see what the Dark Justiciar did. She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs. On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so. She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.
Madeline: Like... this?
NodeContext: Madeline draws a blade from behind her and holds it in front of her stomach, blade pointed towards her stomach. She is utterly terrified (pose like seppuku)
Player: Start stabbing, and don't stop until I say so.
Madeline: Ah! I'm sorry.
NodeContext: Ah! is a noise of pain as she stabs herself in the stomach and then pulls out the knife. 'I'm sorry' is said in clear pain.
Madeline: Argh. I'm so sorry.
NodeContext: stabs herself again on 'Argh', noise of pain. I'm so so sorry is half crying as she's in agony.
Player: Keep going.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me. An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: I prefer a weapon to a stench, thanks.
Gandrel: Sharp steel is not proof against all the monsters of this world, my friend. A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house. That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: My business here is my own.
Gandrel: As you like. But you needn't be coy - whatever's worth knowing, rest assured she already knows it. Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite. Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: What price is that?
Gandrel: Whatever's easiest to lose and hardest to do without. But the thing I hunt has gone to ground. If she can tell me how to draw him out, I'll pay whatever she asks. But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: Who is it you're hunting?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it. Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: Your coyness is getting boring. Tell me.
Gandrel: You take insult where none is intended, my friend. But fine - I won't add to it. I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive. Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: You can give up your hunt. Astarion's under my protection.
Gandrel: ...I see. Your loyalty is admirable but misplaced. His kind have charm beyond our mortal means to resist. I can show you who he truly is - if you will just tell me where to find him. But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?
Player: Tell him how to find your camp.

Gandrel: You've tracked me down again, my friend. Would that I had as much luck with the beast I'm hunting.
Astarion: You're a monster hunter? I'm surprised - I thought all Gur were vagrant cut-throats.
Player: Ignore the elf. He talks too much.
Gandrel: You should listen to your companion. Next he'll warn you that my people can curse your cow to give only sour milk and will seduce your daughter to a life of roaming. I wish I had half the power settled folk think my people possess. Alas, I am a simple wanderer. A simple wanderer and monster hunter. But I'm no witchdoctor or cut-throat.
Player: I assume you want to kill the hag?
Astarion: Or to make a deal with her. Probably think you can outfox the old dear.
Gandrel: Right, but very wrong. My prey is a vampire spawn - much less impressive than the beast that lives here. His name is Astarion, but I fear he's gone to ground. I was hoping the hag of these lands could help me flush him out, but it seems she is no more.
Player: Well, here he is. This is Astarion.

Gale: Thank you.
NodeContext: You look at the player with a big smile and the words are warm and heartfelt.
Player: What for?
Gale: I'm glad you sought me out. Amid all this merriment I wasn't sure we'd have a chance to speak this evening. I thank you for seeking me out. Amidst all this merriment I wasn't sure we'd have a chance to speak this evening. More's the pity you've already found someone else to make merry with, just the two of you. Wyll's a good man. He may actually be a tried-and-true storybook hero. Then again he's so full of himself it's a small miracle he hasn't resorted to self-cannibalism yet. Far be it from me of course, to question your tastes.
Player: Actually, I may just want to spend the night with you instead of Wyll.
Gale: Indeed? We shared a romantic moment of the mind while cloaked in the Weave, didn't we? And I seem to recall a fond allusion to that moment afterwards. Allow me to make the following proposition: There's a book that circulates in Amn, detailing the first thousand nights of a newlywed king and queen. They turned everything they did into an art. The art of conversation. The art of taste, time honoured and newly acquired. The art of the body. The exploration and acceptance of the self and the other. The art of the night itself. I say we take a page from their book.
Player: Leave it to you to woo someone with a book.
Gale: Forget the book then. Let's be blank slates on blank sheets, delightfully new. What do you say?
Player: I'm afraid I have to decline.
Gale: Too bad. One should never be afraid to live life to the fullest. But before you go... I know there are many things about me that remain shrouded in mystery. You've been very patient with me, and I appreciate that. You've given me powerful magic to consume when I needed it most. You've brought me back from the grey shores of death. You know of my condition, and you know about my unfortunate efforts to win Mystra's favour, but those are but the broad strokes. The time has come to paint you the true picture.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me. An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: We share a profession, it seems. I'm Wyll - better known as the Blade of Frontiers.
Gandrel: Ah, the Blade of Frontiers! You wield that reputation as deftly as a blade itself. Your name should serve you well when you meet with the lady of this house. A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house. That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: It's a teahouse - hardly a lair.
Gandrel: A charming sight, to be sure. But the prettiest web still has a spider sitting at its centre. Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite. Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: So I learned.
Gandrel: Ah - so you did. I thought you were just squinting from the stink. But, one fool to another, I can't say I judge you. The thing I hunt has slipped away from me. If she can tell me how to flush him out, I'll pay whatever price she asks. But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: I'd advise against helping such a creature thrive. What quarry could be worth that price?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it. Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: Maybe I can help with your hunt.
Gandrel: No. This duty is mine alone. But for such an offer, an answer at least is owed. I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive. Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: I know Astarion - he's no vampire.
Gandrel: So you have met him. His kind have charm beyond our mortal means to resist. But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?
Player: Tell him how to find your camp.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Is that so? Enigmatic soul, aren't you? A word of advice then - you might not get as warm a welcome as in days gone by. GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: The way things are going, it might well come to that. Some well-to-do's in the city donated enough to see the newcomers right for the time being. Only they didn't bother helping everyone else. Locals going without while strangers feast - it's stoked the fire, all right. [description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: This isn't what I expected... this is much more. The Crown of Karsus. And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: Karsus? Crown? You might need to catch me up a bit...
Gale: Karsus. The child-who-would-become-a-god. He was the most powerful wizard ever known... and he attempted to unseat the goddess of magic herself. Only she used the last of her power to block him from the Weave. His magic faltered. The great flying cities of Netheril plunged from the sky. Karsus' Folly. That goddess of magic was reborn as Mystra. She ruled on, while Netherese magic was reduced to mere fragments of what Karsus once wielded - artefacts, the most powerful of which appears to be his Crown. The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall. If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: To what end?
Gale: To every end you can imagine, and a thousand more beyond. Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations. I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: Mortals are far better guardians of their fates than the gods. We have more to lose.
Gale: Then you're already wiser than me. That's a lesson I've only recently learned. I worshipped Mystra loyally for years, and in that time she granted me the barest sliver of the power I was ready to wield. Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us. Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: And you believe yourself to be that successor?
Gale: Not until this moment, but I can't help beginning to see such a destiny unfold before me. Powerful as he was, Karsus lacked some advantages I can lay claim to. I know Mystra - intimately. And I carry a fragment of the Weave itself within my body. Karsus achieved many things, but he never managed that. A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: What you're suggesting is blasphemy. You'd be wise to banish these notions from your head.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully. I've spent so long feeling... inferior, shut out from my destiny over such a simple act of youthful enthusiasm. Perhaps I got carried away with the thought this Crown could give me back what Mystra took. Cure me, even.

Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?

Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create. General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall. You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: As you mention serving Ketheric, he sent you to find a relic, no?
Balthazar: General Thorm to you. But yes, recovering the relic is the crux of it. He commands, and I, his humble servant, fulfil that command. While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
Balthazar: Telling you will not make the task any less perilous. Just obey, and use your ignorance as a shield. You should be adept at that already. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: You have resources to spare - give me something to aid my search.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell... ...Hmm. Misplaced, it seems. You will be capable enough without it.
Player: This sounds like your problem, not mine. Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do. I'll see what I can do.

Fist Marcus: My old friend. Very good to see you again.
NodeContext: Said knowingly, with maybe a wry sarcastic touch. They don't really know each other, but he pretended to to get you off the hook with Jaheira.
Fist Marcus: Glad to see you earned Jaheira's trust. That's no mean feat.
Player: Are we the only True Souls in this place?
Fist Marcus: For now. I suppose General Thorm sent you to help with my mission. That's all right. I don't mind sharing the glory. I have orders from General Thorm in Moonrise Towers. We can work together. I don't mind sharing the Absolute's glory.
Narrator: *This man takes orders from General Thorm, helping him may be just what you need to gain deeper access to the cult.*
Player: I've heard enough - whatever your mission, it ends here.
Fist Marcus: You'll help me, or you'll stay out of my way. Isobel - the Sel√ªnite cleric that guards this place. General Thorm wants her alive.
Player: Why that cleric specifically?
Fist Marcus: The General speaks for the Absolute. And I don't question the Absolute. Aye. I hope she'll see reason, but if that fails, I'll have to initiate more... extreme measures. And I'll expect your help in the fight.
Player: You can count me in.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: # Mizora's Exit sequence #
Wyll: Holy hells.
Player: Come to gloat, Mizora? We found a letter claiming Ravengard died.
Mizora: I come to bargain. The Hells demand witness.
Narrator: *Your parasite links with Wyll's, and your memories flow into him. He sees his father's flight from Wyrm's Rock and hears Mizora's words to you.*
Wyll: Father is dead? Godsdamned devil. Why are you here?
Mizora: Sisters.
Arbiter Cirrus: Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: A contract appears in the air, glowing. It is Wyll's contract.
Mizora: Your contract, Wyll. Signed in blood, forged in fire, bound in bone - but not unbreakable.
Player: Then break it already. Wyll doesn't need to wait six months.
Mizora: No contract is ended without sacrifice. A cost must be paid.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you. Option one. I show you the way to your father. I guarantee him no harm except that from you and your allies. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal. Option two. I break your pact. You are freed from your duty but retain your devil form. Your father dies by his enemy's hand. Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Mizora: Silence, Karlach!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Let your father die. When the city's free, you can take his place.

Vlaakith: Inquisitor W'wargaz was potent. We are impressed.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The Inquisitor frowns at your insolence.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith, unfazed in the least, considers you with critical interest.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face the player at their eye level.

Shadowheart: Good. Whatever happens to us, the lich queen must not take the artefact.

Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire. As long as they live, the Prism is compromised. Find the one inside and kill them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed. You must accept. Refuse, and know my fury.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: shot of player and whatever remaining gnomes are alive panting, catching their breath. Wulbren appears and claps slowly
Wulbren Bongle: That was a hell of a show, my friend. Watchers collapse in the street as we speak, and the Foundry? The scent of runepowder drifts through the city like a warm embrace - I see my bomb did the trick. Watchers collapse in the street as we speak. The city thanks you - I thank you. But it's not over - so long as a single parasitic Gondian remains, Baldur's Gate is under threat.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Wulbren, enough. The Gondians are no more - I am all that is left. You've won. Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home and mourn my daughter in peace. Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home, and to hold my daughter.
Player: What about Gortash? What if he forces you to build up his Steel Watch once more?
Gondian Zanner Toobin: I will be long gone from this wretched city before that happens. I am no threat - I am... nothing.
Wulbren Bongle: Please - if a Gondian told me the sky was blue, I'd look outside and check. You Gondians will lie, scheme, and torment this city until your dying breaths. Let's end this.
NodeContext: the mask has truly gone, we see wulbren for what he is - cruel, spiteful and viscious
Barcus Wroot: Wulbren - enough! I won't watch as you poison your soul - and the brilliant future that remains to the Ironhand Gnomes. I thought the Ironhand Gnomes had corrupted you, Wulbren. Now I wonder if it wasn't the other way around. Kill the Gondians, and you kill all we love: Collaboration. Challenge. Solving problems with the power of reason, creativity, and invention. I still want to believe you're better than that, Wulbren. But even I am having my doubts.
Player: Wulbren makes a good point - you must die for the city, Gondians.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale takes book out (of his own inventory),
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: This isn't what I expected... this is much more. The Crown of Karsus. And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: A design you could follow?
Gale: Not from scratch - unless you happen to have several pounds of the purest Netherese metals in that pack of yours? Don't worry - I'm not asking you to surrender anything else on my account. What's called for here is something altogether different. The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall. If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: We already know the crown's dangerous. Wouldn't that make things worse?
Gale: Worse? It could be the best thing that ever happened to me. To us. Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations. I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: Don't dare to assume why I worship. Not all of us share such transactional relationships with our gods.
Gale: But do you not expect something in return for your devotion? Some favour, some stir of courage, some response? I worshipped Mystra loyally for years, and in that time she granted me the barest sliver of the power I was ready to wield. Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us. Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: So you want the Crown to settle a score with Mystra?
Gale: She sent me to die. Ambition is not a sin. To question the powers that rule us is not treason. We must at least try - why wallow in the dirt when we can reach for the stars? A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: Gale - I'm urging you to drop this. This Crown cannot be reforged.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully. I've spent so long feeling... inferior, shut out from my destiny over such a simple act of youthful enthusiasm. Perhaps I got carried away with the thought this Crown could give me back what Mystra took. Cure me, even.

Narrator: *Behind the Watcher's gaze, a presence awakens. You are seen, you are known.* *Your infernal machinery seems to snap to attention, almost singing in recognition.*
Karlach: Whoa. My engine. It's almost... I don't know. Buzzing. Like it's paying attention.
Narrator: *Your party's prior transgressions are reflected in its stare, as witnessed by the cult's ever-alert scrying eyes.* *It has heard the howls of slaughtered goblins.* *It has seen the deep shadows of Grymforge, and the stone floors left bloodied.* *It knows the cold walls of Moonrise Towers, and the cultists who fell there.* *The Watcher speaks directly into your mind with a voice like poisoned honey.*
GROUP_SteelWatchers: You are marked for special treatment. Not simply an enemy of the people, but an enemy of the Absolute. Come quietly, or die.
Player: Ready yourself for a fight.

Player: You think a few shadows could beat me?
Alfira: ...Wait. No one's told you? We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Someone told them to rot in the Nine Hells, that we weren't going anywhere. Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Which one was Asharak again?
Alfira: Which...? Back in the grove, he ran drills with the kids. Wooden swords and the like. That seems like a lifetime ago now. Rolan, of all people, saved us. He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: I know - Rolan isn't happy with me.
Alfira: Can you blame him? His brother and sister are gone. He's... dealing with it as best he can. We all are. How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: It helps to remember what is at stake - I fight for nature, for balance. I fight for life itself.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then. You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there. If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

Player: I don't understand. What do you mean?

Empty as a stare. A tadpole's puppet, nothing more. He spoke in accusations. Apostasy, conspiracy, sedition. I'll be executed in five dawns. You might have unlocked my cell, but there's no escape from this place.
Wyll: The Hells with that. Nothing is over. Not while I still draw breath.
Player: You said you wouldn't give up. I'm setting you free and holding you to it.
Counsellor Florrick: Forget it. Baldur's Gate's good as cinder. An illithid hive beyond saving.
Narrator: *You recall the tales of Gorion's Ward, the great hero of Baldur's Gate. Without them, the city would have succumbed to war, famine, and worse.*
Player: I pull you from flames, and this is how you repay me? Find your courage and fight!
Counsellor Florrick: 'When the people need a miracle, you cannot wait for the gods to answer.'
Wyll: Father's words.
Counsellor Florrick: Indeed. To think I'd almost forgotten. No more sulking. I know what to do. And I can only do it with the help of the Blade. No more sulking. I know what to do. Araj Oblodra: Welcome back, True Soul. Just a little prick and it's all over. Close your eyes. A little pain for a lot of gold. And... There we are. All of your very best traits in a bottle. Use it well! Although perhaps there's one more thing we could discuss: your vampiric friend.
Astarion: Don't worry, we're all friends under the Absolute. I won't bite.
Araj Oblodra: Oh I'd prefer if you did. I assume he belongs to you?
Player: We travel together - that's all.
Araj Oblodra: Ah, it's like that. Do you have a name, spawn?
Astarion: Astarion, but hold on-
Araj Oblodra: Good. Now, Astarion, I've dreamt of being bitten by a vampire since I was a young girl.
Astarion: I'm sorry? You want to be bitten?
Araj Oblodra: To feel your life's blood slipping away? To dance on the edge between life and death? Yes, I want it. I'll even compensate you - a potion of legendary power that forever increases the strength of the one who consumes it. It's not for sale, but it's yours if you bite me.
Astarion: I will have to decline.
Araj Oblodra: Excuse me? This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity and you're squandering it.
Astarion: I gave you my answer.
Araj Oblodra: Can't you talk some sense into your obstinate charge?
Player: I am surprised, Astarion. I thought you'd jump at a chance like this.
Astarion: I'm sorry, but could you excuse us a moment? Are you actually asking me to do this? Trading me for some potion? Because there's something wrong with her blood. I can smell it from here - it's rank.
Player: This is your choice - do what you want.
Astarion: All right. Thank you. It's still a no, I'm afraid.

Counsellor Florrick: Leave me. It's over.

Your father's a tadpole's puppet, Wyll. Nothing more. Empty as a stare. A tadpole's puppet, nothing more. He spoke in accusations. Apostasy, conspiracy, sedition. I'll be executed in five dawns. You might have unlocked my cell, but there's no escape from this place.
Jaheira: The Fist can go hang themselves - we're getting you out.

Player: Coward. Balduran didn't build the Gate for you to weep as it burns. Gorion's Ward overcame great odds to protect the city. You can do the same.

Lead me from my cell, escort me out of Wyrm's Rock. I'll seek out my connections. When the city's streets shatter, you'll want their blades.

Vlaakith: You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: Friend - I came to bring it back to you.
Shadowheart: Fool - that artefact is the only thing keeping us safe. She cannot have it.
Vlaakith: An unexpected servant. Your will is strong. Your kind's stoic endurance will be a boon to our cause. Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning. The Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I shall cleanse it for you, my queen. Tell me how.
InternalNodeContext: He's not altogether sure why this task is falling to the player and not to him, but also doesn't want to challenge his queen's motivations.
Vlaakith: SILENCE, W'wargaz. There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight. They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire. As long as they live, the Prism is compromised. Find the one inside and kill them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed. You must accept. Refuse, and know my fury.
Player: I will do as you wish.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face. Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create. General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall. You and all the rest have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make. You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: Touch me, and I'll strike you down with all of nature's fang and fury. Go ahead - try me. You're hiding from shadows - literally. Don't make threats you can't back up.
Balthazar: ...Fine. I'll forgive your transgressions this time - there are much grander things at stake.
NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course. Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: You have resources to spare - give me something to aid my search.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell... ...Hmm. Misplaced, it seems. You will be capable enough without it.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Cerys: Thought you'd be ten yards tall, the way Zevlor spoke of you.
NodeContext: Blunt, eyeing us up (friendly, not unimpressed - but muted due to circumstances)
Cerys: Cerys. Scout. Seems we missed one another at the grove, but the others told me how you helped us. A pity. You pulled them from one death-trap only for me to land them in this one.
Player: So you managed to miss all that trouble at the grove. Convenient.
Cerys: I was trying to scout a path for us while you got busy carving one. But don't worry, I've had my fill of fighting since. Aye, and more than half the others with him. We were ambushed out in the cursed lands - cultists of this Absolute. Likely we should have surrendered, but... They were toying with us. Making examples. And we'd had enough of taking it. Those of us who cut free just kept running 'til we found this place. The others... maybe the cult got them. Maybe the curse.
Player: Coward.

Arabella: I don't see any - wait. Here they come! Sorry. Knocks the wind right out of me.
Player: What are you doing out here? It's not safe.
Arabella: I was looking. For mum and pops. When Zevlor - when he - Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran. I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't.
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*
Player: I'll think about it. My hands are full with these cultists.
Arabella: Fine. Whatever. I don't need you - I'll find them myself!
Player: You're going to get yourself killed. I'll find them, all right?
Arabella: Thanks so much. I knew you'd help me again! The vines won't last forever. I don't - I don't s'pose I can stay with you?
NodeContext: Slightly unsure of herself.
Arabella: Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!
Player: I was just poking at the rancid dog-meat of your parents' corpses.
Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.
Player: And are you tough enough?
Arabella: I'll prove it. Let me help in the camp, til you bring mom and pops back to me. Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!
Player: Forget the search. Your parents are dead.
Arabella: You lie! They're out there. And if you won't find 'em, I will!
NodeContext: Found out her parents are dead. Distraught - her sorcerous powers begin to manifest, intensifying her emotional state.
Player: Do what you want. I'm not stopping you.

Gale: Thank you.
NodeContext: You look at the player with a big smile and the words are warm and heartfelt.
Player: I'm sure you're welcome.
Gale: There's that confidence I like. I thank you for seeking me out. Amidst all this merriment I wasn't sure we'd have a chance to speak this evening. More's the pity you've already found someone else to make merry with, just the two of you. Wyll's a good man. He may actually be a tried-and-true storybook hero. Then again he's so full of himself it's a small miracle he hasn't resorted to self-cannibalism yet. Far be it from me of course, to question your tastes.
Player: Actually, I may just want to spend the night with you instead of Wyll.
Gale: Indeed? We had a moment, you and I, a moment in which we expressed the possibility of becoming more than friends. Tonight seems perfectly suited for such endeavours. Allow me to make the following proposition: There's a book that circulates in Amn, detailing the first thousand nights of a newlywed king and queen. They turned everything they did into an art. The art of conversation. The art of taste, time honoured and newly acquired. The art of the body. The exploration and acceptance of the self and the other. The art of the night itself. I say we take a page from their book.
Player: Leave it to you to woo someone with a book.
Gale: Forget the book then. Let's be blank slates on blank sheets, delightfully new. What do you say?
Player: I'm not sure you're the one I want.
Gale: That's because you've yet to find out what you're missing. Doubt is a spoilsport. Cast it aside.
Player: No. Another time maybe.
Gale: Too bad. One should never be afraid to live life to the fullest. But before you go... I know there are many things about me that remain shrouded in mystery. You've been very patient with me, and I appreciate that. You've given me powerful magic to consume when I needed it most. You've brought me back from the grey shores of death. You know of my condition, and you know about my unfortunate efforts to win Mystra's favour, but those are but the broad strokes. The time has come to paint you the true picture.

Gale: If my suspicions are correct, the crown currently perched atop the elder brain may be one of Karsus' design. And now we hold the very tome that could confirm it.
Player: Don't stand on ceremony - see what it says.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale takes book out (of his own inventory),
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: This isn't what I expected... this is much more. The Crown of Karsus. And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: Stay silent.
Gale: The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall. If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: That Crown's caused chaos. We should be seeking a way to destroy it, not make it more powerful.
Gale: Do not mistake the crown itself for the actions of its wearer, or rather, those controlling its wearer at present. If we could restore its former glory, it would no longer be a mere leash and collar, used to subjugate friend or foe. It would be something greater. Something divine. Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations. I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: Mortals are far better guardians of their fates than the gods. We have more to lose.
Gale: Then you're already wiser than me. That's a lesson I've only recently learned. I worshipped Mystra loyally for years, and in that time she granted me the barest sliver of the power I was ready to wield. Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us. Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: This is no ordinary artefact, Gale. Do this and you'd challenge the gods themselves.
Gale: Perhaps they deserve to be challenged. Perhaps you and I deserve better than to live and die as their pawns. Ambition is not a sin. To question the powers that rule us is not treason. We must at least try - why wallow in the dirt when we can reach for the stars? A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: Gale - I'm urging you to drop this. This Crown cannot be reforged.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully. I've spent so long feeling... inferior, shut out from my destiny over such a simple act of youthful enthusiasm. Perhaps I got carried away with the thought this Crown could give me back what Mystra took. Cure me, even.

Shadowheart: You're here. Just like it told me. And with a gith - I should have figured.
Narrator: *Your mind rushes into hers - a storm of desperation, confusion and a will other than her own.*

Shadowheart: It took me so long to find you.
Player: What's wrong? You seem different than before.
Shadowheart: No questions! I can't... concentrate with all these voices! Just listen. The whispering won't let me sleep. It keeps pushing me - to you. Even when I'm awake, I dream. There's blood, there's so much blood. I can't sleep. The whispering won't let me. It keeps pushing me - to you.
NodeContext: On, " to you" SH's hand drifts toward a knife tucked into her belt at the small her back
Gale: Careful! She's about to lash out.
Narrator: *There is a knife hidden in her belt. Her fingers twitch towards the hilt, ready to draw the blade.*
Player: Slow down - what whispering?
Shadowheart: They've been in my head ever since... it doesn't matter. They brought me here. I keep thinking about the knife going deep. It's the only thing they want me to see. And I think they'll stop once I deal with you.
Player: You can't kill me just because some 'whispers' told you to.
Shadowheart: I can't see anything else! I can't shake it. The whispering's already quieter here. Once you're dead, it'll be gone entirely.
Player: You're exhausted - not thinking straight. You need to rest.
Shadowheart: Rest where? I can't leave. The whispers won't let me leave.
Player: Attack her.

Ben Golewits: The place was empty! Keep those thugs away from my family!
Arfur Gregorio: Zenovia, get these squatters out of my house now.
NodeContext: Indignant at the situation and frustrated at the lack of action from Zenovia and company
Zenovia Dawg: Arfur, sweetheart - you paid me and my boys to be caravan guards, not cattle wranglers. If you want us to get our hands dirty, it'd be our pleasure - but that'll be extra.
Player: Calm down and tell me what's going on.
Arfur Gregorio: I just want to remove these unlawful interlopers from my property!
Player: Relax. You don't need all this space, these people do. Everyone wins.
Ben Golewits: My point exactly!
Arfur Gregorio: Pft, they're like kobolds - you let one in and soon the place will be crawling with them!
Karlach: Ye gods, this guy is begging to get smacked.
Narrator: *This man's indignant demeanour barely masks a seething anxiety. There's more to this situation than he's letting on.*
Arfur Gregorio: I'm a very magnanimous individual, but this is my home. Either they leave, or I'll make them.
Player: In that case, perhaps I can help you out.
Ben Golewits: What d'you mean by that?
Zenovia Dawg: Shhh, sweetheart - adults are talking. This is Guild business and we'll handle it - as soon as we get paid.
Arfur Gregorio: Enough of this bickering! You - what's your proposal?
NodeContext: Snapping; wants to know what's what
Player: I'll get them out of your house for free.
Arfur Gregorio: Old family motto: never trust anyone who works for free. What's in it for you?
Player: I really just quite enjoy brutalising the poor.

Gale: Thank you.
NodeContext: You look at the player with a big smile and the words are warm and heartfelt.
Player: Spontaneous thank-yous make me suspicious.
Gale: Come now! This is a night for celebration, not suspicion. I thank you for seeking me out. Amidst all this merriment I wasn't sure we'd have a chance to speak this evening. More's the pity you've already found someone else to make merry with, just the two of you. Lae'zel. Blade like a razor, wit like a razor, tongue like a razor. I do hope you know what you're doing. Far be it from me of course, to question your tastes.
Player: Actually, I may just want to spend the night with you instead of Wyll.
Gale: Indeed? We had a moment, you and I, a moment in which we expressed the possibility of becoming more than friends. Tonight seems perfectly suited for such endeavours. Allow me to make the following proposition: There's a book that circulates in Amn, detailing the first thousand nights of a newlywed king and queen. They turned everything they did into an art. The art of conversation. The art of taste, time honoured and newly acquired. The art of the body. The exploration and acceptance of the self and the other. The art of the night itself. I say we take a page from their book.
Player: You're remarkably upfront about your intentions.
Gale: I'm many things, but coy's not one of them. What do you say?
Player: I'm not sure you're the one I want.
Gale: That's because you've yet to find out what you're missing. Doubt is a spoilsport. Cast it aside.
Player: No. Another time maybe.
Gale: Too bad. One should never be afraid to live life to the fullest. But before you go... I know there are many things about me that remain shrouded in mystery. You've been very patient with me, and I appreciate that. You've given me powerful magic to consume when I needed it most. You've brought me back from the grey shores of death. You know of my condition and its challenges, but those are but the broad strokes. The time has come to paint you the true picture.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale takes book out (of his own inventory),
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: That devil Raphael was telling the truth. There's no doubt - the Crown of Karsus is what's controlling the elder brain. And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: Karsus? Crown? You might need to catch me up a bit...
Gale: Karsus. The child-who-would-become-a-god. He was the most powerful wizard ever known... and he attempted to unseat the goddess of magic herself. Only she used the last of her power to block him from the Weave. His magic faltered. The great flying cities of Netheril plunged from the sky. Karsus' Folly. That goddess of magic was reborn as Mystra. She ruled on, while Netherese magic was reduced to mere fragments of what Karsus once wielded - artefacts, the most powerful of which appears to be his Crown. The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall. If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: To what end?
Gale: To every end you can imagine, and a thousand more beyond. Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations. I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: Mortals are far better guardians of their fates than the gods. We have more to lose.
Gale: Then you're already wiser than me. That's a lesson I've only recently learned. I worshipped Mystra loyally for years, and in that time she granted me the barest sliver of the power I was ready to wield. Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us. Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: So you want the Crown to settle a score with Mystra?
Gale: She sent me to die. Ambition is not a sin. To question the powers that rule us is not treason. We must at least try - why wallow in the dirt when we can reach for the stars? A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: Gale - I'm urging you to drop this. This Crown cannot be reforged.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully. I've spent so long feeling... inferior, shut out from my destiny over such a simple act of youthful enthusiasm. Perhaps I got carried away with the thought this Crown could give me back what Mystra took. Cure me, even.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me. An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: Whatever you're hunting, your stench alone will kill it.
Gandrel: Hah! A quick wit is rare indeed. Good manners, however, all beings can aspire to. I suggest you find yours before dealing with the lady of this house. A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house. That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: Are you talking about Auntie Ethel?
Gandrel: A gentle name. But I speak of her nature. Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite. Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: Speak for yourself - I got what I wanted.
Gandrel: So said the fish 'round the hook in its mouth. But, one fool to another, I can't say I judge you. The thing I hunt has slipped away from me. If she can tell me how to flush him out, I'll pay whatever price she asks. But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: Who is it you're hunting?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it. Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: There's enough deception in this place - don't add to it.
Gandrel: It is not everyone who can see past her parlour tricks. As you wish - the truth is not mine to keep. I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive. Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: You're wasting your time. Astarion's been dealt with.
Gandrel: You know him? Not too well, I think, if you believe he is so easily slain. He could be stalking your camp at this very moment. Perhaps you could tell me where to look, and I could ensure peace of mind for us both? But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?
Player: Tell him how to find your camp.

Alfira: You're all right! Thank goodness, I was worried they'd got you too.
NodeContext: Relieved. Trying to be cheerful but you're upset, and just holding it together.
Player: I heard what happened - that people were taken to Moonrise.
Alfira: I keep replaying it... over and over in my head. We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Ikaron was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.
 Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Which one was Asharak again?
Alfira: Which...? Back in the grove, he ran drills with the kids. Wooden swords and the like. That seems like a lifetime ago now. Rolan, of all people, saved us. He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: I know - Rolan isn't happy with me.
Alfira: Can you blame him? His brother and sister are gone. He's... dealing with it as best he can. We all are. How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: To linger in the past is to condemn our future. Focus on the here and now.
Alfira: You make it sound so easy - but I'll try. You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there. If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Nere mentioned that you were seeking access to the Temple. Looks like you found it.
Balthazar: Perhaps you'd be more useful dead than alive if you don't even know what I'm seeking here. But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Something called the Nightsong. Your notes were very interesting. Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: Because I am magical powerhouse. You need me, and you know it. It's simple - you need me. Don't pretend otherwise.
Balthazar: ...Fine. Your usefulness may outweigh your insolence - for now. There are much grander things at stake.
NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course. Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: This sounds like your problem, not mine. Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do. I'll see what I can do.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale takes book out (of his own inventory),
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: This isn't what I expected... this is much more. The Crown of Karsus. And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: Stay silent.
Gale: The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall. If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: You 'think'? What happens if you fail?
Gale: Well, there'd be risk in such an endeavour, but only proportionate to the reward.
NodeContext: Doesn't want to get bogged down by doubts like these
Gale: Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations. I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: You dismiss the entire pantheon so easily. Not all gods are selfish.
Gale: Some gods may delude themselves into believing they care about their worshippers, but when it comes down to it - we're all expendable. Children to be appeased, not respected. I worshipped Mystra loyally for years, and in that time she granted me the barest sliver of the power I was ready to wield. Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us. Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: So you want the Crown to settle a score with Mystra?
Gale: She sent me to die. Ambition is not a sin. To question the powers that rule us is not treason. We must at least try - why wallow in the dirt when we can reach for the stars? A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: Gale - I'm urging you to drop this. This Crown cannot be reforged.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully. I've spent so long feeling... inferior, shut out from my destiny over such a simple act of youthful enthusiasm. Perhaps I got carried away with the thought this Crown could give me back what Mystra took. Cure me, even.

Araj Oblodra: Welcome back, True Soul. I'd like to offer my services, if you're willing?
Player: What does a 'trader in blood' do exactly?
Araj Oblodra: I trade in blood and the potions that can be wrung from it. I'm more than happy to make you one, if you'd honour me with your blood. With one drop, I can brew a rather potent potion for you. The rest, I keep for myself.
Player: Sounds interesting. Let's do it.
Araj Oblodra: Just a little prick and it's all over. Close your eyes. A little pain for a lot of gold. And... There we are. All of your very best traits in a bottle. Use it well! Although perhaps there's one more thing we could discuss: your vampiric friend.
Astarion: Don't worry, we're all friends under the Absolute. I won't bite.
Araj Oblodra: Oh I'd prefer if you did. I assume he belongs to you?
Player: Yes. All mine.
Araj Oblodra: Well, I hope you don't mind sharing him for just a minute. Do you have a name, spawn?
Astarion: Astarion, but hold on-

Astarion: I'm sorry? You want to be bitten?
Araj Oblodra: To feel your life's blood slipping away? To dance on the edge between life and death? Yes, I want it. I'll even compensate you - a potion of legendary power that forever increases the strength of the one who consumes it. It's not for sale, but it's yours if you bite me.
Astarion: I will have to decline.
Araj Oblodra: Excuse me? This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity and you're squandering it.
Astarion: I gave you my answer.
Araj Oblodra: Can't you talk some sense into your obstinate charge?

Gale: Thank you.
NodeContext: You look at the player with a big smile and the words are warm and heartfelt.

Gale: Come now! This is a night for celebration, not suspicion. I thank you for seeking me out. Amidst all this merriment I wasn't sure we'd have a chance to speak this evening. More's the pity you've already found someone else to make merry with, just the two of you. Wyll's a good man. He may actually be a tried-and-true storybook hero. Then again he's so full of himself it's a small miracle he hasn't resorted to self-cannibalism yet. Far be it from me of course, to question your tastes.
Player: Actually, I may just want to spend the night with you instead of Karlach.
Gale: Indeed? We shared a romantic moment of the mind while cloaked in the Weave, didn't we? And I seem to recall a fond allusion to that moment afterwards. Allow me to make the following proposition: There's a book that circulates in Amn, detailing the first thousand nights of a newlywed king and queen. They turned everything they did into an art. The art of conversation. The art of taste, time honoured and newly acquired. The art of the body. The exploration and acceptance of the self and the other. The art of the night itself. I say we take a page from their book.
Player: You're remarkably upfront about your intentions.
Gale: I'm many things, but coy's not one of them. What do you say?
Player: I'm afraid I have to decline.
Gale: Too bad. One should never be afraid to live life to the fullest. But before you go... I know there are many things about me that remain shrouded in mystery. You've been very patient with me, and I appreciate that. I was given powerful magic to consume when I needed it most. You've brought me back from the grey shores of death. You know of my condition, and you know about my unfortunate efforts to win Mystra's favour, but those are but the broad strokes. The time has come to paint you the true picture.
