Player: You dismiss the entire pantheon so easily. Not all gods are selfish.
Gale: Some gods may delude themselves into believing they care about their worshippers, but when it comes down to it - we're all expendable. Children to be appeased, not respected. I worshipped Mystra loyally for years, and in that time she granted me the barest sliver of the power I was ready to wield. Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us. Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: Or to destroy the next wizard who attempts it. The attempt would kill you as it killed Karsus.
Gale: Do you think I had not considered that? I have no intention of repeating his folly. Powerful as he was, Karsus lacked some advantages I can lay claim to. I know Mystra - intimately. And I carry a fragment of the Weave itself within my body. Karsus achieved many things, but he never managed that. A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: The pursuit of knowledge and power is in our nature. There's no question - you must do this.

Withers: ...Not this one. Nor this one. And this one, less worthy still...
InternalNodeContext: Hirelings intro
Player: What are you doing?
Withers: Righting the balance. Beyond mortal realms, there doth exist an amalgamation of spirits akin to thine own, ensnared by the treacherous cult of the Absolute, felled in its name. They bear great discontentment with their destiny. For a mere pittance of coin, I might summon the worthiest among them to lend aid to thy undertaking.
Player: I would like to resurrect someone. I need to resurrect someone.
Withers: Then thou must return with the proper payment.
Player: I want to resurrect [CAMP_Jergal_PlayerToResurrect_1_c85cdca4-6579-776d-206d-6967e4999281].
Withers: This is the price of balance. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: Changed my mind. They can stay dead for now.
Withers: Dost thou require anything else? Then thou must return with the proper payment.

Withers: Dost thou require a resurrection?

Withers: Which of them dost thou require?
Player: I'd like you to return Minsc. Changed my mind. They can stay dead for now.
Withers: Dost thou require a resurrection?
Player: I need to resurrect someone.
Withers: Then thou must return with the proper payment.
Player: I want to resurrect [CAMP_Jergal_PlayerToResurrect_3_56966d5e-534d-4930-264e-050a2345db3d]. Here's the gold.

Gale: I must admit, the Crown of Karsus has occupied my every thought since we learned of it. If we can seize it, and use it... the possibilities are endless. Yet you haven't uttered a peep one way or the other about it. The power to change the world - it may be within our reach. You must have an opinion, surely.
Player: I don't know what to say. How can I respond to something so... immense? It's beyond comprehension.
Gale: Then the fault lies with me, and my inadequate words. Please, allow me to show you instead. Just close your eyes a moment. Words alone are not enough. Permit me to show you. Please, close your eyes a moment.
Player: Close your eyes.
Gale: Astra navigabimus.
NodeContext: Latin spellcasting - ass-tra navi-gah-mus ('we sail the stars')
Gale: Few mortals ever glimpse what you're about to see. But don't be alarmed - I'm here with you. Now... open your eyes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up from black as the player opens their eyes to a dazzling spectacle. They and Gale are now sitting in a small boat that shimmers with iridescent light. Unpiloted, it silently meanders through a majestic, infinite starfield.
Gale: The Outer Planes. This is where gods dwell. Where they observe us from afar. Where they make play-things of us. They would keep all of this from us - the power, the possibilities. They only want us to serve them, pray to them... and ultimately, die for them. But what if we didn't need them? What if we wielded their power instead, and helped ourselves in all the ways they refuse to. I could make that happen. I could make this illusion a reality, with you by my side.
Player: You'd defy Mystra? As if we need more enemies.
Gale: I've already defied Mystra. Had I followed her command, there'd be nothing left of me but a smoking crater. The tadpoles, the orb - these threats to our existence - the gods could aid us if they wished, but instead they cower behind Ao. So let us act ourselves.
NodeContext: Ao = AY-oh (an overlord deity that most gods answer to)
Gale: With the power of the crown, any foe would be rendered impotent. Any obstacle would be dwarfed by our might. I used to believe Mystra's forgiveness was worth dying for. But I was wrong. You showed me just how much I have to live for. With you, I forget my goddess. I love you. Tell me you feel the same way. Tell me you want what I want. Please.
Player: I feel the same. Whatever you need of me, consider it done.
Gale: Right now, I need nothing more than a kiss. Then we'll face what is to come, together. And claim the crown when the time comes.
Player: Let's not grow complacent - that path you speak of is sure to be a dangerous one.
Gale: No doubt it will be - abominably so. As is just about everything we do. But I know we're up to the task. Are you still with me? You mean... you want the same as I do?
NodeContext: Hope rising again
Player: I can't, Gale. This is best forgotten. I love you as you are.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale's shoulders sag. The starfield around seems to dim. Distant points of light vanish into the infinite dark.
Gale: What more is there to be said?
Player: Plenty, in time. This doesn't have to be the end for us - just forget the crown.
Gale: But I could be so much more to you.
NodeContext: crestfallen
Player: Say nothing. Answer him with a kiss instead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player and Gale lean in to kiss while seated facing each other.
Gale: You put the stars to shame. Let's sit here another while - I want to drink you in.

Arabella: Please. I'm sorry!
Rath: This is madness, Kagha. She's just a...
Kagha: A what, Rath? A thief? A poison? A threat? I will imprison the devil. And I will cast out every stranger.
Narrator: *A death viper. You have milked their poison before. A single drop of it could kill that child in a heartbeat.*
Player: Thief? Poison? What's this girl's actual crime?
Kagha: Girl? You mean parasite. She eats our food, drinks our water. Then steals our most holy idol in thanks! Rath - lock her up. She remains here until the rite is complete. And keep still, devil. Teela is restless.
Rath: Come, Kagha. We took back the idol. Surely...
Kagha: Do it.
Narrator: *The death of a child. A timeless tragedy that never grows old.*
Player: Free the whelp, or I run your belly through with a blade.
Kagha: The devil sowed chaos. She remains until the rite is complete!
Narrator: *The snake hisses, its intentions unclear.*
Player: Prepare to attack.
Astarion: Yes! Let's have some fun.
Lae'zel: Let judgement be cast. Spill blood after, if you must.
Player: Change your mind.
Lae'zel: Wise. To know, we must first observe.
Kagha: Do it.
Narrator: *The death of a child. A timeless tragedy that never grows old.*
Player: Tell the snake to put Kagha at ease. The girl belongs with her own brood.
Teela: A new hatchling? Yes. They can be foolish. Kagha si nay. Wux geou fulla wer fanol.
NodeContext: To Kagha. Draconic snakey language. KA-ga see-NAY. wooks gyow fulla wur FAN-ole.
Kagha: Ssifisv - it is as you say, Teela. Come to me.
NodeContext: To Teela the snake. A snake-like sound: ss-ifff-iss-ff. A draconian language word. Commanding serpents to stand down.
Kagha: Out, thief. My grace has its limits.

Gale: I owe you an apology. Things became quite heated between us before, after I learned of the Crown of Karsus. I allowed myself to get carried away, and failed to properly explain myself.
Player: Apologies are useless if you're still intent on doing something dangerous.
Gale: When are we not doing something dangerous? Give me a chance - I think I can help you understand. Words alone are not enough. Permit me to show you. Please, close your eyes a moment.
Player: Close your eyes.
Gale: Astra navigabimus.
NodeContext: Latin spellcasting - ass-tra navi-gah-mus ('we sail the stars')
Gale: Few mortals ever glimpse what you're about to see. But don't be alarmed - I'm here with you. Now... open your eyes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up from black as the player opens their eyes to a dazzling spectacle. They and Gale are now sitting in a small boat that shimmers with iridescent light. Unpiloted, it silently meanders through a majestic, infinite starfield.

What if we wielded their power instead, and helped ourselves in all the ways they refuse to. I could make that happen. I could make this illusion a reality, with you by my side.
Player: You're still determined to do this, after all that was said?
Gale: How could I not crave this? But I don't want it for myself, alone - I want you at my side, willing and wholehearted. The tadpoles, the orb - these threats to our existence - the gods could aid us if they wished, but instead they cower behind Ao. So let us act ourselves.
NodeContext: Ao = AY-oh (an overlord deity that most gods answer to)
Gale: With the power of the crown, any foe would be rendered impotent. Any obstacle would be dwarfed by our might. I used to believe Mystra's forgiveness was worth dying for. But I was wrong. You showed me just how much I have to live for. With you, I forget my goddess. I love you. Tell me you feel the same way. Tell me you want what I want. Please.
Player: I feel the same. Whatever you need of me, consider it done.
Gale: Right now, I need nothing more than a kiss. Then we'll face what is to come, together. And claim the crown when the time comes.
Player: You know I would if I could. But I'll sit with you as long as you'll have me.
Gale: I'll always have you, Karlach.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player and Gale are seated facing each other but do not lean in to kiss.
Gale: You see me as I am, and do not find me wanting. With these stars as my witness, I swear - you will always be enough for me.

Gale: Even in such fraught times as these, there is peace to be found in the stillness as evening draws in. I used to while away many hours just like these with my companion, though in far comfier surrounds. She preferred it when we were alone, curled up before a crackling hearth with some ancient, esoteric tome between us, ink glinting in the firelight...
Player: Are you... are you talking about your cat?
Gale: By Ahghairon's lost nose - no! Tara is not any cat. She's a tressym. And given your confusion, I'm guessing you've never met one. They're brilliant creatures - fine company for any self-respecting wizard. I speak of Tara, my tressym, assistant, my constant companion through all the ills and tribulations my hubris has thrust upon me. She'd be most impressed by our efforts saving these tieflings. Proud, even. And I've given her little to be proud of recently. After I was afflicted with my condition, I locked myself in my tower for an entire year. I was inconsolable, wallowing in my self-inflicted tragedy. I'd given up on myself, but Tara never did. It was her encouragement, her research that led me to my treatment. Once we knew that magically-infused items were the key, she went out to find them for me. She saved my life. After so long being cared for by someone else, it feels good to have repaid the favour. Not directly to Tara, but to these poor tieflings. I'm sure she would approve.
Player: What is Tara like?
Gale: 'Smart' does her a disservice. She's a fine wizard in her own right, though somewhat held back by her lack of opposable thumbs. You remind me of her somewhat. You share her fierceness, and her passion. I wish she were here for me to make a formal introduction, but I would never ask her to undertake such a journey. She is safer at home. Besides, she was always telling me I needed to spread my wings, so to speak. Find mortal friends, instead of hanging onto Mystra's coattails. So that's what I'm doing. I hope.
Player: She sounds like a fine animal. One I'd be honoured to know.
Gale: She'll love you. So long as you don't rub her belly. She hates it when anyone does that.
Player: Not as much as I hate talking about cats. Is there nothing else on your mind?
Gale: Not an animal lover? Nobody's perfect, I suppose. Nonetheless, your finer qualities are remarkably plentiful. Suffice it to say, I think rather a lot of you. And there aren't many on this plane who I'd give such high praise.
Player: Being mentioned in the same breath as your pet isn't the compliment you think it is...
Gale: Then let me say it more plainly - I think you're rather wonderful. And that's not a word I waste on anyone unworthy of it.
Player: Actually, I was thinking we'd be wonderful together...
Gale: Wait. Are you saying... You know what, I think I've clearly had far too much wine. And you've had nowhere near enough. I think this is a conversation best held back on - for now. With my condition as volatile as it is, I fear any undue, er, excitement, may tip it over the edge. So to speak. Go, indulge in the frivolities - they're good for the heart. And mine will be all the lighter, to see you enjoying yourself.

Player: I'm flattered. Is your good opinion so hard to come by?
Gale: One doesn't become the most powerful archmage in Waterdeep and lover to the goddess of magic herself by having low standards. I assure you, when I tell someone they're wonderful - I mean it. And you are wonderful. I think you're rather wonderful. And that's not a word I waste on anyone unworthy of it.
Player: Don't stop now. What else do you like about me?

My ineloquent tongue isn't worthy of your ear at present. With my condition as volatile as it is, I fear any undue, er, excitement, may tip it over the edge. So to speak. Go - enjoy your evening. Nothing better for the heart than a good night's rest, and mine is gladdened to know I'll have the pleasure of your company again come morning.

Withers: Fate spins along as it should. Have you need of my services?
Player: You were sorting something before. What were you doing? Impressive. Are there other ways you can help us?
Withers: Should thou or any of thy compatriots perish, I will cleave soul to body once more.
Player: That's incredibly powerful magic. Why is it so easy for you?
Withers: Because it is my calling. There is little else to explain.
Player: You mentioned a cost - what is it?
Withers: A matter of coin. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: At least that's straightforward. I want to resurrect someone.
Withers: Very well. Speak their name and it shall be done. Then thou must return with the proper payment.
Player: I want to resurrect [CAMP_Jergal_PlayerToResurrect_1_c85cdca4-6579-776d-206d-6967e4999281].

Withers: Dost thou require a resurrection?
Player: I would like to collect one of my fallen companions.
Withers: Which of them dost thou require?
Player: I'd like you to return Karlach. Changed my mind. They can stay dead for now.
Withers: Dost thou require a resurrection?
Player: I didn't mean to kill Alfira. Please bring her back.
Withers: The bard's death is a weight for thine own conscience to bear. She will be left to the peace of eternity, where the Urge shall seek her no more. Dost thou require a resurrection?
Player: I need to resurrect someone.
Withers: Then thou must return with the proper payment.

Gale: A beautiful night, don't you think? Nothing like a brush with destruction to make one appreciate the majesty of the celestial canvas. It's a view I would once have shared with my companion. Though definitely unaccompanied by such revelry. She preferred it when we were alone, curled up before a crackling hearth with some ancient, esoteric tome between us, ink glinting in the firelight...
Player: Are you... are you talking about your cat?
Gale: By Ahghairon's lost nose - no! Tara is not any cat. She's a tressym. And given your confusion, I'm guessing you've never met one. They're brilliant creatures - fine company for any self-respecting wizard. I speak of Tara, my tressym, assistant, my constant companion through all the ills and tribulations my hubris has thrust upon me. She'd be proud to see me keeping such fine company - the saviour of those poor tieflings, no less. And I've given her precious little to be proud of recently. She has a good heart, and she would recognise the same in your actions here. I'm sure she'd approve of me lending myself to your efforts. After so long being cared for by someone else, it feels good to have repaid the favour. Not directly to Tara, but to these poor tieflings. I'm sure she would approve.
Player: What is Tara like?
Gale: 'Smart' does her a disservice. She's a fine wizard in her own right, though somewhat held back by her lack of opposable thumbs. You remind me of her somewhat. There's a steeliness to you, an unwavering tenacity even in the face of, to be frank, quite dire odds. I wish she were here for me to make a formal introduction, but I would never ask her to undertake such a journey. She is safer at home. Besides, she was always telling me I needed to spread my wings, so to speak. Find mortal friends, instead of hanging onto Mystra's coattails. So that's what I'm doing. I hope.
Player: What if she doesn't like me?
Gale: She'll love you. So long as you don't rub her belly. She hates it when anyone does that.
Player: Not as much as I hate talking about cats. Is there nothing else on your mind?
Gale: Not an animal lover? Nobody's perfect, I suppose. Nonetheless, your finer qualities are remarkably plentiful. Suffice it to say, I think rather a lot of you. And there aren't many on this plane who I'd give such high praise.
Player: Don't stop there. What else do you like about me?
Gale: Were I to recite that list, I fear we'd still be here at dusk tomorrow. Many things, I assure you, but a conversation better saved for another time. Perhaps we'd better leave it at that. My ineloquent tongue isn't worthy of your ear at present. With my condition as volatile as it is, I fear any undue, er, excitement, may tip it over the edge. So to speak. Go, indulge in the frivolities - they're good for the heart. And mine will be all the lighter, to see you enjoying yourself.

Withers: Because it is my calling. There is little else to explain.

Gale: I must admit, the Crown of Karsus has occupied my every thought since we learned of it. If we can seize it, and use it... the possibilities are endless. Yet you haven't uttered a peep one way or the other about it. The power to change the world - it may be within our reach. You must have an opinion, surely.
Player: I don't know what to say. How can I respond to something so... immense? It's beyond comprehension.
Gale: Then the fault lies with me, and my inadequate words. Please, allow me to show you instead. Just close your eyes a moment. Words alone are not enough. Permit me to show you. Please, close your eyes a moment.
Player: Close your eyes.
Gale: Astra navigabimus.
NodeContext: Latin spellcasting - ass-tra navi-gah-mus ('we sail the stars')
Gale: Few mortals ever glimpse what you're about to see. But don't be alarmed - I'm here with you. Now... open your eyes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up from black as the player opens their eyes to a dazzling spectacle. They and Gale are now sitting in a small boat that shimmers with iridescent light. Unpiloted, it silently meanders through a majestic, infinite starfield.
Gale: The Outer Planes. This is where gods dwell. Where they observe us from afar. Where they make play-things of us. They would keep all of this from us - the power, the possibilities. They only want us to serve them, pray to them... and ultimately, die for them. But what if we didn't need them? What if we wielded their power instead, and helped ourselves in all the ways they refuse to. I could make that happen. I could make this illusion a reality, with you by my side.
Player: You'd defy Mystra? As if we need more enemies.
Gale: I've already defied Mystra. Had I followed her command, there'd be nothing left of me but a smoking crater. The tadpoles, the orb - these threats to our existence - the gods could aid us if they wished, but instead they cower behind Ao. So let us act ourselves.
NodeContext: Ao = AY-oh (an overlord deity that most gods answer to)
Gale: With the power of the crown, any foe would be rendered impotent. Any obstacle would be dwarfed by our might. I used to believe Mystra's forgiveness was worth dying for. But I was wrong. You showed me just how much I have to live for. With you, I forget my goddess. I love you. Tell me you feel the same way. Tell me you want what I want. Please.
Player: I feel the same. Whatever you need of me, consider it done.
Gale: Right now, I need nothing more than a kiss. Then we'll face what is to come, together. And claim the crown when the time comes.
Player: Wait. Perhaps I'm being too hasty... and perhaps you're overreaching.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale's shoulders sag. The starfield around seems to dim. Distant points of light vanish into the infinite dark.
Gale: What more is there to be said?
Player: Plenty, in time. This doesn't have to be the end for us - just forget the crown.
Gale: But I could be so much more to you.
NodeContext: crestfallen
Player: You're already everything I need you to be.
Gale: I hope you're right. I truly do. Godly power, perhaps I can live without, but you? You're everything.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player and Gale lean in to kiss while seated facing each other.
Gale: You see me as I am, and do not find me wanting. With these stars as my witness, I swear - you will always be enough for me.

Gale: Thank you.
NodeContext: You look at the player with a big smile and the words are warm and heartfelt.
Player: Spontaneous thank-yous make me suspicious.
Gale: Come now! This is a night for celebration, not suspicion. I thank you for seeking me out. Amidst all this merriment I wasn't sure we'd have a chance to speak this evening. More's the pity you've already found someone else to make merry with, just the two of you. You might be in for an adventure with Karlach. More than you bargained for - with a bit of luck. Or perhaps more than you bargained for - full stop. Far be it from me of course, to question your tastes.
Player: Actually, I may just want to spend the night with you instead of Astarion.
Gale: Indeed? Perhaps that's a moment we ought to further explore. Allow me to make the following proposition: There's a book that circulates in Amn, detailing the first thousand nights of a newlywed king and queen. They turned everything they did into an art. The art of conversation. The art of taste, time honoured and newly acquired. The art of the body. The exploration and acceptance of the self and the other. The art of the night itself. I say we take a page from their book.
Player: Leave it to you to woo someone with a book.
Gale: Forget the book then. Let's be blank slates on blank sheets, delightfully new. What do you say?
Player: I'm not sure you're the one I want.
Gale: That's because you've yet to find out what you're missing. Doubt is a spoilsport. Cast it aside.
Player: You're right. I'd like to spend the night with you.

Gale: Ah, you've a moment for me? I was hoping to speak to you - I confess, my thoughts have been somewhat scattered since my audience with Mystra. A pity I did not learn all she had to offer, but the fact that she summoned me to her presence is proof enough that the Crown of Karsus is worth pursuing. The Karsite Weave could offer more than just power - it could bestow divinity. If I only trust myself to wield it. The power to change the world - it may be within our reach. You must have an opinion, surely.
Player: I don't know what to say. How can I respond to something so... immense? It's beyond comprehension.
Gale: Then the fault lies with me, and my inadequate words. Please, allow me to show you instead. Just close your eyes a moment. Words alone are not enough. Permit me to show you. Please, close your eyes a moment.
Player: Close your eyes.
Gale: Astra navigabimus.
NodeContext: Latin spellcasting - ass-tra navi-gah-mus ('we sail the stars')
Gale: Few mortals ever glimpse what you're about to see. But don't be alarmed - I'm here with you. Now... open your eyes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up from black as the player opens their eyes to a dazzling spectacle. They and Gale are now sitting in a small boat that shimmers with iridescent light. Unpiloted, it silently meanders through a majestic, infinite starfield.
Gale: The Outer Planes. This is where gods dwell. Where they observe us from afar. Where they make play-things of us. They would keep all of this from us - the power, the possibilities. They only want us to serve them, pray to them... and ultimately, die for them. But what if we didn't need them? What if we wielded their power instead, and helped ourselves in all the ways they refuse to. I could make that happen. I could make this illusion a reality, with you by my side.
Player: Are you saying you want to ascend? Claim godhood?
Gale: No, not like that. I don't want to join them, I want to better them. A god's powers, paired with a mortal conscience, a mortal heart. The tadpoles, the orb - these threats to our existence - the gods could aid us if they wished, but instead they cower behind Ao. So let us act ourselves.
NodeContext: Ao = AY-oh (an overlord deity that most gods answer to)
Gale: With the power of the crown, any foe would be rendered impotent. Any obstacle would be dwarfed by our might. I used to believe Mystra's forgiveness was worth dying for. But I was wrong. You showed me just how much I have to live for. With you, I forget my goddess. I love you. Tell me you feel the same way. Tell me you want what I want. Please.
Player: I feel the same. Whatever you need of me, consider it done.
Gale: Right now, I need nothing more than a kiss. Then we'll face what is to come, together. And claim the crown when the time comes.
Player: Let's not grow complacent - that path you speak of is sure to be a dangerous one.
Gale: No doubt it will be - abominably so. As is just about everything we do. But I know we're up to the task. Are you still with me? You mean... you want the same as I do?

Player: Yes. I want you to seize the crown, and make us a new world.
Gale: I've never wanted to kiss you more than I do now.

Gale: Thank you.
NodeContext: You look at the player with a big smile and the words are warm and heartfelt.
Player: What for?
Gale: I'm glad you sought me out. Amid all this merriment I wasn't sure we'd have a chance to speak this evening. I thank you for seeking me out. Amidst all this merriment I wasn't sure we'd have a chance to speak this evening. More's the pity you've already found someone else to make merry with, just the two of you. There's something... unspeakable about Shadowheart. But I mean that in a good way. She seems to me like a bud on the cusp of bursting into a rose. That or deadly nightshade. Far be it from me of course, to question your tastes.
Player: Actually, I may just want to spend the night with you instead of Shadowheart.
Gale: Indeed? We had a moment, you and I, a moment in which we expressed the possibility of becoming more than friends. Tonight seems perfectly suited for such endeavours. Allow me to make the following proposition: There's a book that circulates in Amn, detailing the first thousand nights of a newlywed king and queen. They turned everything they did into an art. The art of conversation. The art of taste, time honoured and newly acquired. The art of the body. The exploration and acceptance of the self and the other. The art of the night itself. I say we take a page from their book.
Player: Leave it to you to woo someone with a book.
Gale: Forget the book then. Let's be blank slates on blank sheets, delightfully new. What do you say?
Player: I think that sounds delightful.

Lae'zel: Can you feel it crawling through you? Tendrils squirming in your chest, gripping your heart, piercing your belly? Your bones popping, your flesh swelling? I can. I see it in you. I feel it in me. We are lost. First you. Then myself.
Narrator: *Your minds intertwine. You sense a touch of uncertainty, a touch of disgust.*
Player: We're just exhausted. Lower the blade before you do something foolish.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Laezel and the player stand [reuse]
Lae'zel: Bah - I cannot trust my own mind. So it seems I must trust yours. I will wait. But know this: I am watching. If the sickness does not pass come dawn... ...I will end us all.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Minthara steps up on the stone tower outside the gate to the Druid Grove, she assumes her imposing posture, arms at her back, she locks gaze with the player
Asharak: If I don't see you after the battle... tell the children I took out the drow.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The archer nocks another arrow, when the army arrives beneath Minthara and lowers the bow to watch
Asharak: Get that damn gate closed! This is it, people. Weapons ready, eyes to the front. Anyone who takes down a worg gets their choice of cut tonight... By Amaunator's Eternal Sun, none of us are dying today!
Narrator: *A splinter of ice works its way into your mind.*
Nightwarden Minthara: A pretty speech. It almost brings a tear to my eye.
NodeContext: amused, referring to the tiefling leaders inspiring speech to the defenders but talking to the player
Nightwarden Minthara: Now slit his throat, and open that gate. The Absolute wants all of them dead.
NodeContext: simple, to the point - killing is a very ordinary thing to her
Player: These people are under my protection - but I'll see you in the Hells.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Minthara steps up on the stone tower outside the gate to the Druid Grove, she assumes her imposing posture, arms at her back, she locks gaze with the player
Zevlor: This is it. Everything turns on this.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The archer nocks another arrow, when the army arrives beneath Minthara and lowers the bow to watch
Zevlor: Get that damn gate closed! I know that you are all afraid... but I also know that you have been fighting your whole lives. We have never been handed the easy choices, or the gentle paths. And this is no different. These creatures would take our lives, our children... our future. And we must resist!

Player: Your god has no power here.

Sazza: Mistress! It's me, yer loyal servant, Sazza. I'm back - an' I brought a friend.
Nightwarden Minthara: A duergar? Tell me, Sazza, did your misadventures take you to the Underdark?
Sazza: They woz in some rickety druid grove! Mostly full of tieflin's, but them intruders you're after were hidin' out there!
Nightwarden Minthara: I presume you dealt with my prey, and massacred the rest?
Sazza: Ah... well, the thing about that is... they sorta massacred us. I got myself nabbed though; ended up all snug in a cage instead of smashed. I'm wily like that. And then the Absolute answered my prayers - sent a True Soul to save me!
Nightwarden Minthara: You are a True Soul. And it seems that the inhabitants of the grove trust you - we can use that against them. You have a part to play in this slaughter. Return to the grove. When my raiding party approaches, throw open the gate and signal me.
Narrator: *The fate of the grove's inhabitants hangs in the balance.* *Killing the drow here would spare them, but it might be better to face her warband at the grove itself, on familiar ground.* *On the other hand, participating in the slaughter as she asks may be the perfect way to earn her trust, and access to the cult's inner circle.*
Player: You misunderstand. I'm here to slaughter you.

Gale: My word, you did it! Ha! Oh, it's good to be alive! My hands are still cold so that handshake will have to wait, but in the meantime: thank you!
Player: It's time for explanations, Gale.
Gale: Yes, I was afraid you'd say that. Only fair to warn you I've precious few answers to spare. I apologise if that sounds thankless. It's just that some secrets simply cannot be revealed.
Player: Tell me, or this'll be a very short-lived return.
Gale: I... I suppose that after all you've done for me, I should be at least a little bit forthcoming. Tell you what: I will answer one question that you may have. To the best of my ability. If I can.
Player: Actually, never mind. If it makes you this uncomfortable, I won't insist.

Sazza: It's past the bridge, to the east! Big ol' gate, covered in ivy! Don't hurt me, mistress. Please!
Nightwarden Minthara: I will not hurt you. My spiders will have that pleasure.
Sazza: No! I mucked up, I'm sorry! But I didn't know who they woz... they didn't tell me nothin'!

Sazza: I told ya! I was tryin' to follow orders best I could!

Nightwarden Minthara: I presume you dealt with my prey, and massacred the rest?
Sazza: Ah... well, the thing about that is... they sorta massacred us. I got myself nabbed though; ended up all snug in a cage instead of smashed. I'm wily like that. And then the Absolute answered my prayers - sent a True Soul to save me!
Nightwarden Minthara: You are a True Soul. And it seems that the inhabitants of the grove trust you - we can use that against them. You have a part to play in this slaughter. Return to the grove. When my raiding party approaches, throw open the gate and signal me.
Narrator: *The fate of the grove's inhabitants hangs in the balance.* *Killing the drow here would spare them, but it might be better to face her warband at the grove itself, on familiar ground.* *On the other hand, participating in the slaughter as she asks may be the perfect way to earn her trust, and access to the cult's inner circle.*
Player: I want no part of this.
Nightwarden Minthara: I do not intend to lead a suicidal charge. The goblins are expendable; I am not. The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates and crush our enemies.
Player: The Absolute has nothing to do with it. I'm here to kill you.

Gale: My word, you did it! Ha! Oh, it's good to be alive! My hands are still cold so that handshake will have to wait, but in the meantime: thank you!
Player: It's time for explanations, Gale.
Gale: Yes, I was afraid you'd say that. Only fair to warn you I've precious few answers to spare. I apologise if that sounds thankless. It's just that some secrets simply cannot be revealed.
Player: I brought you back to life. A few answers is the least you can spare me.
Gale: I... I suppose that after all you've done for me, I should be at least a little bit forthcoming. Tell you what: I will answer one question that you may have. To the best of my ability. If I can.
Player: Actually, never mind. If it makes you this uncomfortable, I won't insist.
